<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>
<h1><a name="_Toc23046347" id="_Toc23046347"></a><a name=
"_Toc26088544" id="_Toc26088544"><span style=
'color:black'>Introduction</span></a></h1>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This document is the second volume in the
three volume set of User&CloseCurlyQuote;s Manuals for the
Micromechanics Analysis Code with Generalized Method of Cells
Version 4.0 (MAC/GMC 4.0).&nbsp; Volume 1 is the Theory Manual,
this document is the Keywords Manual, and Volume 3 is the Example
Problem Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 is a computer code developed at
NASA&nbsp;Glenn Research Center that analyzes the thermo-inelastic
behavior of composite materials and laminates.&nbsp; The code is
based on the micromechanics&nbsp;theory known as the generalized
method of cells (GMC).&nbsp; GMC models the response of composite
materials using a doubly or triply periodic repeating unit cell
(RUC), which is composed of a number of subcells&nbsp;(see Figure
3.1 and Figure 3.2).&nbsp; By placing distinct constituent
materials within the subcells, a heterogeneous (composite) material
can be modeled, provided an RUC can be identified in the
material&CloseCurlyQuote;s micro scale architecture.&nbsp; The main
advantages of GMC over other micromechanics theories and approaches
are: 1) its fully multi-axial formulation, 2) the availability of
local (constituent level) stress and strain fields, and 3) its
computational efficiency.&nbsp; The availability of the local
fields makes the method attractive in situations where more
detailed composite analysis, beyond simple determination of
effective thermo-elastic properties, is necessary.&nbsp; In such
situations, when matrix inelasticity, constituent damage&nbsp;or
failure, or fiber-matrix debonding&nbsp;is important, the
availability of the local fields is critical in order&nbsp;to
account for these effects appropriately.&nbsp; It is the purpose of
the MAC/GMC 4.0 code to provide a convenient and user-friendly
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;package&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; for the GMC
theories, in addition to providing significant added value through
a library of inelastic constitutive models, repeating unit cells,
thermo-mechanical and yield&nbsp;surface loading&nbsp;options,
failure and damage analysis capabilities, and
results&nbsp;generation options.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The original method of cells (which allowed
only four subcells) was developed by Aboudi (1989, 1991), the
doubly periodic version of GMC by Paley and Aboudi (1992), and the
triply periodic version of GMC by Aboudi (1995).&nbsp; The actual
GMC theories implemented within MAC/GMC 4.0 were reformulated for
maximum computational efficiency by Pindera and Bednarcyk (1999)
and Bednarcyk and Pindera (2000).&nbsp; A recent advancement in the
GMC technology has significantly improved the local accuracy of the
doubly periodic version of the model.&nbsp; This new
micromechanics&nbsp;theory, called the high-fidelity generalized
method of cells (HFGMC), developed by Aboudi <i>et al.</i> (2001,
2002), has also been implemented with MAC/GMC 4.0.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">As mentioned, MAC/GMC 4.0 is also capable of
analyzing composite laminates.&nbsp; The composite
laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;capabilities also rely on the GMC
composite material model.&nbsp; The doubly and triply periodic
versions of GMC function within the context of classical lamination
theory&nbsp;(Jones, 1975; Herakovich, 1998) to model the
ply&nbsp;level composite material.&nbsp; Thus, the code can analyze
the thermo-inelastic behavior of arbitrary laminate
configurations.&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Finally, a new thermo-electro-magnetic version
of GMC that is capable of modeling so-called
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;smart&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; composites has
been implemented within MAC/GMC 4.0.&nbsp; The implementation also
enables the analysis of smart composite laminates.&nbsp; This
specific form of the thermo-electro-magnetic GMC was developed by
Bednarcyk (2002) based on the work of Aboudi (2000).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b><i><u><span style=
'font-family:"Verdana",sans-serif'>Details on New
Features</span></u></i></b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>1)&nbsp;&nbsp; The format
of the MAC/GMC 4.0 input file&nbsp;has been completely overhauled.
&nbsp;Unneeded keywords have been eliminated, more logical keyword
and specifier names have been utilized, and the placement of
specific data has been better organized.&nbsp; The result is a
considerably more streamlined and easy to use input file
format.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The memory
allocation&nbsp;of MAC/GMC 4.0 is dynamic.&nbsp; There is no longer
a static limit on the size of the problem (i.e., number of
subcells&nbsp;and laminate&nbsp;plies) that can be analyzed, the
number of constituent materials that can be employed, or the number
of x-y plot&nbsp;result files that can be generated.&nbsp; The
result is a more robust code that only uses the system resources it
needs to execute a given problem.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>3)&nbsp;&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0
can analyze smart&nbsp;composites and laminates.&nbsp; A major
advancement in the generalized method of cells
micromechanics&nbsp;models and lamination theory&nbsp;has been
implemented within MAC/GMC 4.0: the ability to model fully coupled
thermo-electro-magneto-visco-elasto-plastic composite materials and
laminates.&nbsp; These so-called
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;smart&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; materials and
composites react electromagnetically to thermo-mechanical
loading&nbsp;and react mechanically to
electromagnetic&nbsp;loading.&nbsp; These materials are currently
finding a growing number of applications in sensors and actuators
and have the potential to enable the next generation of
multi-functional structures that can automatically sense and react
to various stimuli.&nbsp; See problems 7b and 7c in the MAC/GMC 4.0
Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>4)&nbsp;&nbsp; A new
high-fidelity doubly periodic micromechanics&nbsp;model has been
implemented within MAC/GMC 4.0.&nbsp; This new micromechanics
model, the high-fidelity generalized method of cells (HFGMC)
provides much more accurate local stress and strain field
predictions than does the standard method of cells.&nbsp; MAC/GMC
4.0 can therefore perform composite analyses with a variable level
of fidelity, maximizing either accuracy or efficiency when
appropriate.&nbsp; See problem 3f in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example
Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>5)&nbsp;&nbsp; Several new
internal material constitutive models have been implemented within
MAC/GMC 4.0.&nbsp; These include: a shape memory&nbsp;alloy
constitutive model, the classical incremental
plasticity&nbsp;model, a new
multimechanism&nbsp;visco-elastic-plastic GVIPS&nbsp;model, the
Freed-Walker&nbsp;viscoplasticity model, a Robinson&nbsp;isotropic
viscoplasticity model for NARloy Z, and a completely
anisotropic&nbsp;elastic model.&nbsp; The classical incremental
plasticity model is formulated to allow the user to simply input
stress-total strain point pairs from a material&CloseCurlyQuote;s
inelastic stress-strain curve. &nbsp;See problems 2c, 2d, 7a, and
7e in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>6)&nbsp;&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0
enables the use of an external material database&nbsp;file.&nbsp;
User&CloseCurlyQuote;s can store their own material
properties&nbsp;in this external database file, from which the code
reads and stores only the material properties specified for use in
a specific problem. &nbsp;See problem 2h in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example
Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>7)&nbsp;&nbsp; The
laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;capabilities have been significantly
expanded and computationally enhanced.&nbsp; Discontinuous fiber
and particulate&nbsp;reinforced laminate layers can now be analyzed
thanks to the ability of triply periodic GMC to represent any
particular layer&nbsp;within a laminate.&nbsp; Further, all
laminate data is now kept in core memory during
execution&nbsp;(previous versions of MAC/GMC performed read/write
cycles to disk).&nbsp; This has significantly increased the
computational efficiency of MAC/GMC 4.0 laminate analyses.
&nbsp;See problem 3i in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>8)&nbsp;&nbsp; The
yield&nbsp;surface analysis capabilities of MAC/GMC 4.0 are
significantly expanded.&nbsp; Various subcell and repeating unit
cell level yield surfaces can be automatically generated for
composites using standard or high-fidelity GMC.&nbsp; Further,
yield surfaces can now be automatically generated for laminates on
the laminate, ply, and micro (subcells within a ply) levels.
&nbsp;See problems 4f and 4g the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>9)&nbsp;&nbsp; The static
failure&nbsp;analysis capabilities of MAC/GMC 4.0 have been
significantly enhanced.&nbsp; A simple and quick estimation of
composite allowable stress and strain quantities can be performed
based on the constituent allowables.&nbsp; Further, true subcell
and repeating unit cell level static failure&nbsp;analysis (i.e.,
checking for failure at various scales during application of
simulated thermo-mechanical loading) can be performed using several
failure criteria.&nbsp; These failure analyses are available for
composites as well as laminates. &nbsp;See problems 5a, 5b, and 5c
in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>10) The
fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis capabilities of MAC/GMC 4.0 have
been significantly enhanced.&nbsp; A new strength
reduction&nbsp;fatigue model has been implemented, and the
applicability of the stiffness reduction&nbsp;fatigue model has
been expanded to include triply periodic repeating unit cells and
laminates.&nbsp; Further, both fatigue damage models now work in
concert with the MAC/GMC 4.0 static failure&nbsp;and
interfacial&nbsp;debonding&nbsp;capabilities to enable
mechanistically realistic life predictions for composites and
laminates. &nbsp;See problem 5d in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example
Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>11) The local fiber
failure&nbsp;analysis capabilities of MAC/GMC 4.0 have been
improved via inclusion of the Curtin&nbsp;effective fiber
breakage&nbsp;model.&nbsp; Based on fiber strength&nbsp;statistical
data, the Curtin model is a widely used tool for predicting
composite stiffness degradation and failure due to longitudinal
fiber fracture.&nbsp; The Curtin model can be used to model fibers
within continuous fiber composites and continuous fiber composite
layers within laminates. &nbsp;See problem 5f in the MAC/GMC 4.0
Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>12) The
post-processing&nbsp;of MAC/GMC 4.0 results&nbsp;has been
significantly improved.&nbsp; The code now automatically generates
output&nbsp;for use with the popular MATLAB&nbsp;software
package.&nbsp; MATLAB source&nbsp;files are distributed with
MAC/GMC 4.0 that generate fringe plots&nbsp;of the stress, strain,
and inelastic strain fields predicted by the code. &nbsp;See
problem 6c in the MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Manual.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>13) MAC/GMC 4.0 has been
extensively tested and debugged.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="Note"><span style='font-family:Wingdings'>F</span>
<u>Note:</u>&nbsp; Attempts have been made to enable a high level
of interoperability within MAC/GMC 4.0.&nbsp; However, currently
not all of the code&CloseCurlyQuote;s features can work in
concert.&nbsp; For example, the composite layers within a
laminate&nbsp;cannot currently be modeled using the new
HFGMC&nbsp;micromechanics&nbsp;model.&nbsp; Look for additional
improvements in interoperability in future versions of MAC/GMC.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:18.7pt;text-indent:-18.7pt'><span style=
'font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3><a name="_Toc23046349" id="_Toc23046349"></a><a name=
"_Toc26088546" id="_Toc26088546">Format of this Manual</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:6.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This Keywords Manual first presents a
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Getting Started&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
section that details the installation of the MAC/GMC 4.0 software
and how the code can be executed.&nbsp; The bulk of this manual
presents detailed information on each of the keywords that may
appear in the MAC/GMC 4.0 input file.&nbsp; Each keyword is
presented with its purpose, and then the usage of and all
specifiers associated with the keyword are described.&nbsp;
<span style='color:blue'>Optional</span> and <span style=
'color:blue'>special case</span>&nbsp;specifiers are shown in
<span style='color:blue'>blue</span> type.&nbsp; A
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Notes&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; section for each
keyword is referenced via superscripts in the list of specifiers
and their descriptions.&nbsp; For example, the specifier
<i>t(i)</i> is descibed as,</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" style='margin-left:5.4pt;border-collapse:collapse'>
<tr>
<td width="72" valign="top" style=
'width:.75in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><u><span style=
'font-family:"Verdana",sans-serif'>Name</span></u></p>
</td>
<td width="511" valign="top" style=
'width:383.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><u><span style=
'font-family:"Verdana",sans-serif'>Definition</span></u></p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="72" valign="top" style=
'width:.75in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><i>t(i)</i> <sup>3</sup></p>
</td>
<td width="511" valign="top" style=
'width:383.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">Time points in time vs. load
magnitude&nbsp;profile</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Here, the superscript
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;3&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; would refer to note
number 3 in the &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Notes&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
section, which would follow the above description.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">One or more examples of the usage of each
keyword are given along with any additional information needed to
use the keyword.&nbsp; Any example problems (appearing in the
Example Problem Manual) associated with the particular keyword are
listed, with example problems that are most relevant to the keyword
typed in <b>bold</b>.&nbsp; Suggested sources of additional
information are also provided when appropriate.&nbsp; In some
cases, keyword information is broken into subsections in
order&nbsp;to facilitate the presentation of the needed
information.&nbsp; Note that the abbreviation <span style=
'color:red'>N/A</span> is employed throughout this manual to
indicate that a particular option is not applicable or
unavailable.&nbsp; Finally, &ndash; AND &ndash;&nbsp; and&nbsp;
&ndash; OR &ndash;&nbsp; are used as logical operators.</p>
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>

Started</span></a></h1>
</div>

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046352"
id="_Toc23046352"></a><a name="_Toc26088549" id=
"_Toc26088549">Executing MAC/GMC 4.0 Problems</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The MAC/GMC 4.0 executable
file&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4.exe</span></span>)
is a DOS&nbsp;executable file intended to be executed through
Microsoft Windows<sup><span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&Oacute;</span></sup>&nbsp;(NT, 2000, XP) at
the command prompt.&nbsp; In order&nbsp;to execute a MAC/GMC 4.0
problem, at the command prompt, in the directory containing the
executable, type:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4</span></span>&nbsp;
<i>in_name&nbsp; <span style='color:blue'>out_name</span></i></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">where,</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" style='margin-left:5.4pt;border-collapse:collapse'>
<tr>
<td width="50" valign="top" style=
'width:37.7pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><i>in_name</i></p>
</td>
<td width="533" valign="top" style=
'width:399.7pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 input file&nbsp;name</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="50" valign="top" style=
'width:37.7pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><i><span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i></p>
</td>
<td width="533" valign="top" style=
'width:399.7pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 output&nbsp;file&nbsp;name
<i><span style='color:blue'>(Optional)</span></i></p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The code will look for the input
file&nbsp;with the specified <i>in_name</i> and a
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>.mac</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
extension, so the specified <i>in_name</i> should not include an
extension.&nbsp; The <i><span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i> <span style=
'color:black'>specification is optional</span><span style=
'color:black'>.&nbsp; If</span> <i><span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i> is omitted, the code will use the
specified input file name and write output&nbsp;to the file
<i>in_name</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>.out</span></span>.&nbsp;
If <i><span style='color:blue'>out_name</span></i> <span style=
'color:black'>is specified and does not have an extension, the code
will write output to the file</span> <i><span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>.out</span></span>.&nbsp;
Finally, if <i><span style='color:blue'>out_name</span></i>
<span style='color:black'>is specified and does have an extension,
the code will write output to the file</span> <i><span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i> <span style='color:black'>with the
specified extension.&nbsp; If the desired input and output
file</span><span style='color:black'>&nbsp;locations are different
than the current working directory</span><span style=
'color:black'>, the directory path</span><span style=
'color:black'>&nbsp;can be added to the specified <i>in_name</i>
and</span> <i><span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i><span style=
'color:black'>.</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style='color:black'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><u>Example</u>:&nbsp; Execute MAC/GMC 4.0
using the input file&nbsp;&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>example_1a.mac</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
located in the &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
directory, write output&nbsp;to the file
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>example_1a.out</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
located in the &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
directory.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>C:\mac4&gt;mac4

<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=

<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">As the above text indicates, MAC/GMC 4.0
performs a self-diagnostic
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;prescan&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; step prior to
executing a given problem.&nbsp; During this prescan, the input
file is checked for errors.&nbsp; If errors are detected,
execution&nbsp;of the problem will not be completed, and a
description of the detected errors will be written to the
output&nbsp;file.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The MAC/GMC 4.0 input, output, and
results&nbsp;data files can be viewed and edited with any standard
ASCII&nbsp;file editor (such as Microsoft NotePad&nbsp;or Microsoft
WordPad).&nbsp; Alternatively, MAC/GMC 4.0 can be set up to execute
within a programming environment, such as Microsoft Visual
Workspace.&nbsp; The best way to do this is to compile&nbsp;and
link&nbsp;the MAC/GMC 4.0 library file&nbsp;and the
user-defined&nbsp;subroutines within the programming environment,
as described in the next section.&nbsp; The MAC/GMC 4.0 files can
then be conveniently manipulated within the utilized programming
environment.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><i><u><span style=
'text-decoration:none'>&nbsp;</span></u></i></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046353"
id="_Toc23046353"></a><a name="_Toc26088550" id=
"_Toc26088550">Using User-Defined Subroutines with MAC/GMC
4.0</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The MAC/GMC 4.0 static library file, along
with the three MAC/GMC 4.0 user-defined&nbsp;subroutines, are
included on the MAC/GMC 4.0 distribution cd in the
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>library</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
file folder.&nbsp; The contents of the
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>library</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
folder are:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" style='margin-left:5.4pt;border-collapse:collapse'>
<tr>
<td width="120" valign="top" style=
'width:1.25in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4.lib</span></span></p>
</td>
<td width="463" valign="top" style=
'width:347.4pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 static library file</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="120" valign="top" style=
'width:1.25in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>usrformde.</span></span><span class=

<span class=

<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>usrmat.</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>F90</span></span>
is employed)</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="120" valign="top" style=

<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=

<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>usrfun.</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>F90</span></span></p>

<td width="463" valign="top" style=

</tr>
<tr>
<td width="120" valign="top" style=

<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>usrfun.</span></span><span class=

<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-top:12.0pt'>In order&nbsp;to
generate a MAC/GMC 4.0 executable file&nbsp;from these four files,
the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>.F90</span></span> source&nbsp;files
must be compiled and linked with the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4.lib</span></span>&nbsp;static
library file&nbsp;using an appropriate Microsoft
Windows<sup><span style=
'font-family: Symbol'>&Oacute;</span></sup>&nbsp;(NT, 2000, XP)
FORTRAN&nbsp;90 compiler.&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0 was developed using the
Compaq Visual Fortran&nbsp;product (v. 6.6), and it is thus
recommended that this product be used.&nbsp; For information on
this product, see: <a href=
"http://www.compaq.com/fortran/">http://www.compaq.com/fortran/</a></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The procedure for creating the MAC/GMC 4.0
executable from the four files above within Compaq Visual
Fortran&nbsp;involves:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">1) Create new fortran console application
project:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
a) Click &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;File&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;New&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Projects&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; Tab
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> select
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Fortran Console
Application&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> specify Location
(directory&nbsp;path) and Project name and click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;OK&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b) Select &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;An empty
project&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; to create, click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Finish&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; and click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;OK&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">2) Add files to the project:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
a) Click &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Project&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Add to Project&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Files&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b) Select the MAC/GMC 4.0 static library file&nbsp;and the three
user defined source&nbsp;files</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:.5in'>
listed above from the appropriate directory&nbsp;and click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;OK&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">3) Choose
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Release&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; configuration
to maximize execution&nbsp;speed</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
a) Click &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Build&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Set Active Configuration
&hellip;&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b) Select &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;&hellip; Win32
Release&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; and click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;OK&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">4) Build (compile&nbsp;and link) the
executable</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
a) Click &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Build&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Build
<i>project</i><i>_name</i>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
b) Alternatively, just hit F7 on the keyboard</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This procedure will build&nbsp;an executable
MAC/GMC 4.0 file in the
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Release&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
directory.&nbsp; If a debug&nbsp;version is desired (which will
allow the debugging of the user-defined&nbsp;subroutines only), the
active configuration can be set to
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Debug&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">To execute MAC/GMC 4.0 problems using this
executable file&nbsp;from within the Compaq Visual
Fortran&nbsp;&nbsp;environment:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>1) Click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Project&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Settings&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>2) Make sure that on the
left the &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Settings For:&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
box has the appropriate configuration listed and that the
project&nbsp;name (rather than one of the source&nbsp;files or the
library file) is highlighted.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>3) On the right, choose
the &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Debug&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; tab</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>4) Under
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Program arguments:&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;,
type:&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>in_name&nbsp; <span style=
'color:blue'>out_name</span></i> (as you would after typing
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
at for execution&nbsp;via the DOS&nbsp;command prompt) and click
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;OK&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:13.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>5) Select
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Build&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;Execute
&hellip;&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; to run the code.&nbsp;
(Alternatively hit the <span style=
'font-family:"Arial Rounded MT Bold",sans-serif; color:red'>!</span>
toolbar button)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Note that the MAC/GMC 4.0 input, output, and
data results&nbsp;files can be viewed and edited within the Compaq
Visual Fortran&nbsp;environment.&nbsp; The
user-defined&nbsp;FORTRAN&nbsp;90 source&nbsp;files can also be
edited within this environment.&nbsp; It is important for the user
to realize that the three provided user-defined FORTRAN 90 source
files contain code that is used to demonstrate the MAC/GMC 4.0
user-defined capabilities.&nbsp; These same three subroutines are
complied and linked into the MAC/GMC 4.0 distribution executable
file&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>mac4.exe</span></span>).&nbsp;
If users wish to employ their own code in the user-defined
subroutines, this code must be placed in the three user-defined
FORTRAN 90 source files, and these files must be compiled and
linked to the MAC/GMC 4.0 static library file&nbsp;(see procedure
above).&nbsp; It is the user&CloseCurlyQuote;s responsibility to
ensure that his code is functioning properly and that his code is
actually being utilized during execution&nbsp;rather than the
demonstration code distributed in the three user-defined FORTRAN 90
source files.&nbsp; Note that a message is written to the screen
when the distributed (default) versions of the user-defined
subroutines are called.&nbsp; It is recommended that the user write
a similar message to the screen to serve as notification that the
intended subroutine is being called.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3><a name="_Toc23046354" id="_Toc23046354"></a><a name=
"_Toc26088551" id="_Toc26088551">Format of the MAC/GMC 4.0 Input
File</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The remainder of this Keywords Manual deals
with the specific input requirements of the MAC/GMC 4.0 input
file&nbsp;to execute analyses of composite materials and
laminates.&nbsp; This input file is an ASCII&nbsp;file that can be
edited with any standard ASCII file editor.&nbsp; The first line of
the input file is always interpreted as a title&nbsp;line.&nbsp;
The remainder of the input file is divided into a number of
keywords, which are placed on their own line in the file and are
preceded by the asterisk character (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*</span></b></span>).&nbsp;
A number of input lines follows each keyword, and each line
contains specifier words, followed by an
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;=&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; sign.&nbsp; The
input data read by the code then follows the
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;=&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; sign.&nbsp; An
example of a MAC/GMC 4.0 input file is:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>MAC/GMC 4.0 Example 1a -
graphite</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>/epoxy
effective properties</span></span></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b>*CONDUCTIVITY</b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;NTEMP=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
TEMP=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>21.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char1">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*CONSTITUENTS</span></b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;
NMATS=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>2</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'># -- Graphite
fiber</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp; M=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
CMOD=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>6
MATID=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>U
MATDB=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
&</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
EL=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>388.2E9,7.6E9,0.41,0.45,14.9E9,-0.68E-6,9.74E-6</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
K=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>500.,10.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'># -- Epoxy matrix</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp; M=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>2
CMOD=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>6
MATID=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>U
MATDB=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
&</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
EL=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>3.45E9,3.45E9,0.35,0.35,1.278E9,45.E-6,45.E-6</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
K=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.19,0.19</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char1">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*RUC</span></b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;
MOD=</span></span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>2
ARCHID=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
VF=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.65
F=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
M=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>2</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char1">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*PRINT</span></b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;
NPL=</span></span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>-1</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*END</span></b></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This MAC/GMC 4.0 input file&nbsp;contains five
keywords (highlighted in bold).&nbsp; In addition, the MAC/GMC 4.0
input file recognizes the following two special characters:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" style='margin-left:5.4pt;border-collapse:collapse'>
<tr>
<td width="36" valign="top" style=
'width:27.0pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>#</span></span></p>
</td>
<td width="547" valign="top" style=
'width:5.7in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">Placed at the start of a line, makes the line
a comment (which is ignored by the code)</p>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="36" valign="top" style=
'width:27.0pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&</span></span></p>
</td>
<td width="547" valign="top" style=
'width:5.7in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">Placed at the end of a line, serves as a
continuation character and causes the code to treat the next line
as part of the same line.</p>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">These two special characters&nbsp;are very
important as the the line on which the data specifiers are located
within the MAC/GMC 4.0 input file&nbsp;is important.&nbsp; That is,
examining a portion of the example input file given above,</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'># -- Graphite
fiber</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp; M=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
CMOD=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>6
MATID=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>U
MATDB=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
&</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
EL=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>388.2E9,7.6E9,0.41,0.45,14.9E9,-0.68E-6,9.74E-6</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;&nbsp;
K=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>500.,10.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The specifiers <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>MATID=</span></span>, <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>MATDB=</span></span>, and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>EL=</span></span>&nbsp;are all on
the same line (due to the presence of the &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>&</span></span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
continuation character), but the specifier <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>K=</span></span>&nbsp;is on its own
line.&nbsp; If the correct input file&nbsp;format is not followed,
the code will not execute and the errors detected within the input
file will be described in the output&nbsp;file.&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Finally, the order&nbsp;of the keywords in the
input file&nbsp;is unimportant.&nbsp; The order of the specifiers
on a particular line is also unimportant.&nbsp; As mentioned above,
however, the order of the specifiers that are on different lines
under a particular keyword is important.&nbsp; Despite the freedom
to place the keywords and specifiers on a particular line in any
order, this manual presents a logical suggested order for
both.&nbsp; It is recommended that the user follow this order for
the sake of logic and clarity.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
</div>
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'><br clear="all"
style='page-break-before:auto'></span></span>
<div class="WordSection3">
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>
<h1 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;background:#E0E0E0'>
<a name="_Toc23046355" id="_Toc23046355"></a><a name="_Toc26088552"
id="_Toc26088552">Section 1 <span style='color:black'>: Flag-Type
Keywords</span></a></h1>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The first section of the MAC/GMC 4.0 keywords
involves the flag-type keywords.&nbsp; These three keywords are
like switches that tell the code whether or not to perform certain
analyses or do certain things.&nbsp; Like all keywords, they may be
placed anywhere within the MAC/GMC 4.0 input file, but it is
recommended that they be placed at the beginning of the file.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The three MAC/GMC input file&nbsp;keywords
covered in this section are:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*CHECK</span>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Causes code only to
check the input file&nbsp;without executing.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*CONDUCTIVITY</span>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Causes code to
calculate effective thermal conductivities.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*ELECTROMAG</span>&nbsp;
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Indicates that code
execution&nbsp;will involve electromagnetic&nbsp;(smart)
analysis.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">It should be noted that if <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*CONDUCTIVITY</span> is
specified, there are additional input requirements for and
restrictions on the constituent materials (specified with
<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>).&nbsp;
Similarly, if <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*ELECTROMAG</span> is
specified, additional input requirements are associated with the
constituent materials (specified with <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>),
the repeating unit cell or laminate&nbsp;(specified with
<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*RUC</span>
or <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*LAMINATE</span>), and
the applied mechanical loading&nbsp;(specified with <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*MECH</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><br clear=
"all" style='page-break-before:auto'></span>
<div class="WordSection4">
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046356"
id="_Toc23046356"></a><a name="_Toc26088553" id=
"_Toc26088553">*CHECK</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style='font-size:14.0pt'>Check
input file</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;for errors</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046357"
id="_Toc23046357"></a><a name="_Toc26088554" id=
"_Toc26088554">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Specify that MAC/GMC 4.0 should only check the
input file&nbsp;for errors and then stop.&nbsp; The code will not
execute an analysis or generate any results.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046358"
id="_Toc23046358"></a><a name="_Toc26088555" id=
"_Toc26088555">Usage:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*CHECK</p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046359"
id="_Toc23046359"></a><a name="_Toc26088556" id=
"_Toc26088556">Example:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*CHECK</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046360"
id="_Toc23046360"></a><a name="_Toc26088557" id=
"_Toc26088557">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">None</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046361"
id="_Toc23046361"></a><a name="_Toc26088558" id=
"_Toc26088558">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0 always performs a
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;prescan&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; of the input
file&nbsp;in order&nbsp;to check the data for errors and determine
array dimensions&nbsp;for dynamic memory allocation.&nbsp; The
<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CHECK</span> option
stops the code after the prescan is complete.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp; There are some input data inconsistencies that cannot be
detected during the prescan.&nbsp; Such errors will not be detected
using the <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CHECK</span> option, but will be
detected during analysis execution, causing the code to stop.</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046362"
id="_Toc23046362"></a><a name="_Toc26088559" id=
"_Toc26088559">*CONDUCTIVITY</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Effective thermal
conductivities</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046363"
id="_Toc23046363"></a><a name="_Toc26088560" id=
"_Toc26088560">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Specify that MAC/GMC 4.0 should determine
effective thermal conductivity&nbsp;components at the specified
temperatures.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046364"
id="_Toc23046364"></a><a name="_Toc26088561" id=
"_Toc26088561">Usage:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*CONDUCTIVITY</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp; NTEMP=<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>ntemp</span></span>
TEMP=<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family: "Times New Roman",serif'>T(1),T(2),&hellip;,T(ntemp)</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<table class="MsoNormalTable" border="0" cellspacing="0"
cellpadding="0" style='margin-left:5.4pt;border-collapse:collapse'>
<tr>
<td width="60" valign="top" style=
'width:45.0pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><u><span style=

</td>
<td width="523" valign="top" style=

<p class="MsoNormal"><u><span style=

</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td width="60" valign="top" style=
'width:45.0pt;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal"><i>ntemp</i></p>
</td>
<td width="523" valign="top" style=
'width:5.45in;padding:0in 5.4pt 0in 5.4pt'>
<p class="MsoNormal">Number of temperatures at which to calculate

</td>
</tr>
<tr>

</td>
<td width="523" valign="top" style=

</td>

<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046365"
id="_Toc23046365"></a><a name="_Toc26088562" id=
"_Toc26088562">Example:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*CONDUCTIVITY</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp; NTEMP=3 TEMP=21.,200.,500.</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046366"
id="_Toc23046366"></a><a name="_Toc26088563" id=
"_Toc26088563">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 1a</b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046367"
id="_Toc23046367"></a><a name="_Toc26088564" id=
"_Toc26088564">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0 determines the three effective thermal
conductivity&nbsp;components (in the three Cartesian coordinate
directions) of a GMC repeating unit cell (RUC) at the specified
temperatures as a separate pre-step.&nbsp; This is done prior to
determination of the effective thermo-elastic properties and
application of the simulated loading.&nbsp; The effective thermal
conductivities are printed to the output&nbsp;file&nbsp;and then no
longer stored or used by the code.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; If the <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CONDUCTIVITY</span> keyword is
specified, two thermal conductivity&nbsp;components (axial and
transverse) must be specified for each constituent material read by
MAC/GMC 4.0&nbsp; (see Section 2, <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>).
&nbsp;Further, the material properties&nbsp;of the constituents
must be user-defined&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">MATID=</span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">U</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CONDUCTIVITY</span> keyword is
only compatible with repeating unit cell
analysis&nbsp;(<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*RUC</span>),
not laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*LAMINATE</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4) &nbsp; The effective thermal conductivities are calculated based
on the assumption that all constituent materials are (at most)
transversely isotropic&nbsp;(in terms of their local thermal
conductivities) and that their plane of isotropy is the
x<sub>2</sub>-x<sub>3</sub> plane in global RUC coordinates.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046368"
id="_Toc23046368"></a><a name="_Toc26088565" id=
"_Toc26088565">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 Keywords Manual Section 2
(<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>)</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046369"
id="_Toc23046369"></a><a name="_Toc26088566" id=
"_Toc26088566">*ELECTROMAG</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Electromagnetic analysis</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046370"
id="_Toc23046370"></a><a name="_Toc26088567" id=
"_Toc26088567">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Specify that MAC/GMC 4.0 should perform
coupled thermo-electro-magneto-elasto-visco-plastic analysis.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046371"
id="_Toc23046371"></a><a name="_Toc26088568" id=
"_Toc26088568">Usage:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*ELECTROMAG</p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046372"
id="_Toc23046372"></a><a name="_Toc26088569" id=
"_Toc26088569">Example:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*ELECTROMAG</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046373"
id="_Toc23046373"></a><a name="_Toc26088570" id=
"_Toc26088570">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 7b</b>, <b>Example 7c</b></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046374"
id="_Toc23046374"></a><a name="_Toc26088571" id=
"_Toc26088571">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; Unlike determination of the effective thermal
conductivities, electromagnetic&nbsp;analysis is tightly coupled
within the MAC/GMC 4.0 formulation.&nbsp; Field variables
associated with the thermo-electro-magnetic effects are stored and
tracked during the MAC/GMC 4.0 execution&nbsp;and simulated
electro-magnetic loading&nbsp;must be applied.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; If the <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*ELECTROMAG</span> keyword is
specified, each constituent material read by MAC/GMC 4.0 must
include the electromagnetic&nbsp;specifier: <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
EM=</span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">1</span>
indicates that the constituent material has electromagnetic
material parameters associated with it; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
EM=0</span> indicates that the constituent material does not have
electromagnetic material parameters associated with it (see Section
2, <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>).&nbsp; For
constituent materials with <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
EM=1</span>, electromagnetic material parameters must be specified,
the material&CloseCurlyQuote;s thermo-mechanical material
properties&nbsp;must be user-defined&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">MATID=</span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">U</span>),
and the arbitrary transversely isotropic&nbsp;elastic constitutive
model&nbsp;must be employed (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">CMOD=</span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">9</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; Electromagnetic analysis may be performed for both
repeating unit cell analysis&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*RUC</span>) and
laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*LAMINATE</span>).&nbsp; However,
the electromagnetic&nbsp;materials may only be part of triply
periodic GMC RUCs.&nbsp; That is, if RUC analysis is specified,
triply periodic GMC must be employed (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">MOD=</span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">3</span>).&nbsp;
If laminate analysis is specified, any layer&nbsp;that is
electromagnetic (i.e., contains electromagnetic constituent
materials) must employ triply periodic GMC (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">MOD=3</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; In the case of
electromagnetic&nbsp;laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*LAMINATE</span>), each
layer&nbsp;must include the electromagnetic specifier: <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
EM=</span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">1</span>
indicates that the layer is electromagnetic (see Section 3,
<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*LAMINATE</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; Because electric and magnetic loading&nbsp;terms
must be specified in the case of electromagnetic&nbsp;analysis, the
arbitrary loading&nbsp;option&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">LOP=</span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar">99</span>)
must be employed.&nbsp; The electromagnetic loading history is
specified as mechanical loading&nbsp;components&nbsp;7 &ndash; 12
(see Section 4, <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*MECH</span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046375"
id="_Toc23046375"></a><a name="_Toc26088572" id=
"_Toc26088572">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 Keywords Manual Section 2
(<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>)</p>

(<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*LAMINATE</span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 Keywords Manual Section 4
(<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar">*MECH</span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 Theory Manual&nbsp;Section
2.2.2</p>

</div>
