<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046428"
id="_Toc23046428"></a><a name="_Toc26088608" id=
"_Toc26088608">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 2h</b></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046429"
id="_Toc23046429"></a><a name="_Toc26088609" id=
"_Toc26088609">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>TREF=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>tref</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>is only
required in the special case</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;when
the code cannot determine at what
temperature</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;the
material properties</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;should
be taken.&nbsp; This special case occurs when:</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;font-style:normal'>&CenterDot;</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>Thermal
loading</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;is
not specified (</span></span><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*THERM</span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>omitted)</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
&ndash; AND &ndash;&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;font-style:normal'>&CenterDot;</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>Material
properties are taken from the internal material
database</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;</span></span>(<i>matid</i>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&sup1;</span> <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>U</span></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:9.0pt'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&ndash; OR
&ndash;&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:9.0pt'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>Material
properties are user-defined</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;</span></span>(<i>matid</i>
= <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>U</span></span>)<span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;
&ndash; AND &ndash;&nbsp; temperature</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>-dependent</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; In all other cases <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>TREF=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>tref</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>is
optional</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><u><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>Warning</span></u></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>:
Specifying</span></span> <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>TREF=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>tref</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>will
override the temperature</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;dependence
and cause the code to employ
temperature-independent</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;material
properties</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;for
the material taken at the temperature </span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:blue'>tref</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; In order&nbsp;to use the external material
database&nbsp;feature of MAC/GMC 4.0, the <b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>*MDBPATH</span></b>
keyword must be specified (see Section 1 of this manual).&nbsp; It
is there that the name of the external material database file is
specified.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The format of the material property specification in
the external material database&nbsp;file is very similar to that
employed in the MAC/GMC 4.0 input file&nbsp;for
user-defined&nbsp;material properties.&nbsp; A printout of the
sample external material database file distributed with MAC/GMC 4.0
is given in the appendix of this manual.&nbsp; The same special
characters (&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>#</span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
for a comment, &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>&</span>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
for a continuation) that can be used in the input file can be used
in the external material database file, and the first line of the
file is interpreted as a title.&nbsp; Each material in the file is
specified by a name using the line:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span>
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt; font-family:"Courier New"'>MAT=</span><i>matname</i></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
where</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>matname</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>is the
name of the material.&nbsp; The</span></span> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>matname</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>specified
in the input file</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;should
correspond to one (and only one) of the material names in the
external material database</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;file.&nbsp;
The next line for each material re-specifies the material
constitutive model</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>:</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span>
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt; font-family:"Courier New"'>CMOD=</span><i>cmod</i></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
The code uses this as a consistency</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;check
as it must match the value of</span></span> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>cmod</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>specified
for the material in the input file</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>.&nbsp;
The remainder of the material property input data in the external
material database</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; font-style:normal'>&nbsp;file
follows the format of the user-defined</span></span><span class=

<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>

thermo-electro-magneto-elasto-plastic analysis of

constituent materials to have certain additional
electromagnetic&nbsp;properties.&nbsp; Currently, specification of
these properties is limited in MAC/GMC 4.0 to the case in
which:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>a) The material
constitutive model&nbsp;is the transversely isotropic&nbsp;elastic
model (<i>cmod</i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>=9</span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&ndash;
AND &ndash;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>b)&nbsp; The
material properties&nbsp;are
user-defined&nbsp;(<i>matid</i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>=U</span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp; &ndash; AND
&ndash;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>c)&nbsp; The
material properties&nbsp;are read from the input
file&nbsp;(<i>matdb</i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New"'>=1</span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Thus, the specification of
constituent electromagnetic&nbsp;properties actually falls within
section II. A. of this outline rather than in its own section

<div class="WordSection8">
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>
<h1 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;background:#E0E0E0'>
<a name="_Toc26088616" id="_Toc26088616">Section 3 <span style=
'color:black'>: Analysis Type and Architecture
Keywords</span></a></h1>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This section deals with the keywords used to
select the overall analysis type and the particular
micromechanics&nbsp;model(s) that will be used by MAC/GMC 4.0 to
analyze the particular problem.&nbsp; The two MAC/GMC 4.0 input
file&nbsp;keywords covered in this section are:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:63.0pt;text-indent:-45.0pt'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*RUC</span> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span>&nbsp; Invokes repeating unit cell
(RUC) analysis, that is, models the behavior of a composite
material (continuum)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:94.5pt;text-indent:-76.5pt'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*LAMINATE</span>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Invokes
laminate&nbsp;analysis, therefore models the behavior of a
composite laminate (finite in one direction) with access to
individual ply, RUC, and subcell data</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">RUC analysis&nbsp;allows simulations to be
performed on a heterogeneous (composite) material that is
represented by a repeating unit cell.&nbsp; There are three
separate micromechanics&nbsp;models within MAC/GMC 4.0 that can be
employed in RUC analyses: 1) Doubly periodic generalized method of
cells (GMC), 2) Triply periodic GMC, and 3) Doubly periodic
high-fidelity GMC (HFGMC).&nbsp; The doubly periodic GMC RUC is
shown in Figure 3.1, while the triply periodic GMC RUC is shown in
Figure 3.2.&nbsp; The RUC for doubly periodic HFGMC is identical to
that of doubly-periodic GMC with the current restriction that the
number of subcells&nbsp;in each direction must be even.&nbsp; By
assigning the different constituent materials (specified under
<span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*CONSTITUENTS</span>) to
the subcells within the RUC, the RUC can be constructed to
represent a composite material with the desired architecture.&nbsp;
As the name indicates, the RUC repeats infinitely in either two
(doubly periodic) or three (triply periodic) Cartesian coordinate
directions.&nbsp; The doubly periodic RUC is infinitely long in the
third (out-of-plane) x<sub>1</sub>-direction (see Figure 3.1), so
both RUCs represent an infinite heterogeneous (composite) medium
with a periodic microstructure.&nbsp; Thus, GMC and HFGMC may be
thought of as models for a material point&nbsp;that may be part of
a larger overall structure.&nbsp; These micromechanics models not
only calculate the effective properties&nbsp;of the composite
material located at a particular material point, but also allow the
simulation of applied loading&nbsp;(in the form of global stresses,
global strains, a uniform temperature&nbsp;change, and
electromagnetic&nbsp;loads) on the composite material (see Section
4 of this manual).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Laminate analysis, on the other hand,
simulates the behavior of a structure, namely a laminated
plate.&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0 employs classical lamination
theory&nbsp;(Jones, 1975; Herakovich, 1998) to model the composite
laminate&nbsp;as infinite in the in-plane <i>x</i>- and
<i>y</i>-directions and finite in the
through-thickness&nbsp;<i>z</i>-direction (see Figure 3.3).&nbsp;
Simulated loading&nbsp;for the laminate takes the form of in-plane
stress and moment resultants and midplane strains and curvatures
(see Section 4 of this manual).&nbsp; As Figure 3.3 indicates, each
ply&nbsp;of the laminate may be a composite material, which is then
represented by a doubly or triply periodic GMC RUC.&nbsp; The GMC
micromechanics&nbsp;models are thus embedded&nbsp;within the
laminate theory analysis to represent the composite material points
within the laminate plies.&nbsp; In the presence of laminate
bending and inelastic material behavior, the stress and strain
fields in the laminate will vary nonlinearly in the
through-thickness (<i>z</i>-) direction.&nbsp; In such a case,
MAC/GMC 4.0 tracks the fields in the laminate at two Gauss
quadrature&nbsp;(integration) points in each layer (see Figure
3.3).&nbsp; During incremental application of the applied
laminate-level simulated loading, the appropriate GMC
micromechanics model is called at each of the two integration
points&nbsp;in each layer to determine the local inelastic behavior
of the composite material.&nbsp; The local inelastic behavior
represented by the quadrature points can then be employed to
determine the laminate level inelastic effects, which accounted for
as inelastic force and moment resultants (see the MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 3).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style=
'text-align:center;page-break-after:avoid'><img border="0" width=
"310" height="285" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image015.png"></p>

"_Ref22095147">Figure</a> 3.1&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; <span style=

cell (RUC).&nbsp; The RUC is composed of subcells, each of which
contains a constituent material.&nbsp; The subcells are identified
by the indices</span><span style=
'font-weight:normal'>&nbsp;</span><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;font-weight: normal'>bg</span><span style=
'font-weight:normal'>.&nbsp; Note that for HFGMC,
N<sub>&beta;</sub> and N<sub>&gamma;</sub> must be even.</span></p>

'font-weight:normal'>&nbsp;points.</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style='text-align:center'>

<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046442"
id="_Toc23046442"></a><a name="_Toc26088617" id=
"_Toc26088617">*RUC</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Repeating unit cell analysis and
architecture</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt; color:red'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt; font-family:Wingdings;color:red'>P</span>
<span style='color:red'>Either</span> <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar"><span style=
'color:red'>*RUC</span></span> <span style='color:red'>or</span>
<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar"><span style=
'color:red'>*LAMINATE</span></span> <span style='color:red'>is
required in all input file</span><span style='color:red'>s</span>
<span style=
'font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Wingdings; color:red'>P</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046443"
id="_Toc23046443"></a><a name="_Toc26088618" id=
"_Toc26088618">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Invoke repeating unit cell analysis&nbsp;(as
opposed to laminate&nbsp;analysis) for the problem, which requires
the selection of the micromechanics&nbsp;model used to analyze the
RUC and specification of the RUC architecture&nbsp;(i.e.,
arrangement of the composite constituents).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The RUC section is broken into two
sub-sections:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>I.&nbsp; Internal
RUC Architecture Library (<i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char"><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>&NotEqual;99</span></span>)</p>

<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
VF2=0.15 RAD2=71. RITFR2=0.1 R=1. F=4,1 M=2 I=3,3</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*RUC</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp; MOD=3 ARCHID=0 M=2</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
<span style='font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046446"
id="_Toc23046446"></a><a name="_Toc26088621" id=
"_Toc26088621">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Example 1a-c, Example 1d, Example 2a-h,
<b>Example 3a</b>, <b>Example 3b</b>, <b>Example 3d</b>, <b>Example
3f</b>, Example 4a-c, Example 4f, Example 5a-b, Example 5d-f,
Example 6a-b, Example 7a-b</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
<span style='font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046447"
id="_Toc23046447"></a><a name="_Toc26088622" id=
"_Toc26088622">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; For <i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=9</span></span>,
the fiber volume fraction&nbsp;of fiber 2 is adjusted to preserve
the correct packing&nbsp;arrangement and RUC aspect ratio.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The open cell&nbsp;triply periodic RUC
(<i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=10</span></span>)
places the matrix material&nbsp;(<i>mm</i>) in the four colored
subcells shown in Figure 3.6 (i.e., the
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;arms&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; are the matrix
material).&nbsp; The
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;open&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; material shown in
the figure is occupied by the fiber material.&nbsp; Thus, to
simulated a truly &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;open&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;
material, the fiber elastic stiffness should be set very low so as
to provide little contribution to the overall RUC response.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i><span style=
'color:blue'>modid</span></i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New";color:blue'>=1</span>
is a special case&nbsp;used in MAC/GMC 4.0 to select a monolithic
material.&nbsp; Internally, the code employs a double periodic GMC
RUC analysis&nbsp;with one subcell to which the material is
assigned using <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>M=</span></span><i>mm</i> (see
Example above).&nbsp; A monolithic material may also be selected by
using <i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=0</span></span>
in either doubly or triply periodic GMC.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; Doubly periodic HFGMC&nbsp;RUC
analysis&nbsp;requires an even number of subcells&nbsp;in both the
x<sub>2</sub>- and x<sub>3</sub>-directions and additional
specialized input under the <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar1">*SOLVER</span>
keyword.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The RUC architectures contained within the MAC/GMC
4.0 architecture&nbsp;library&nbsp;are shown in Figure 3.4 (doubly
periodic, no interface), Figure 3.5 (doubly periodic, with
interface), and Figure 3.6 (triply periodic).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
6)&nbsp;&nbsp; The <i><span style='color:blue'>ritfr</span></i>,
<i><span style='color:blue'>mi</span></i>, <i><span style=
'color:blue'>rad</span></i>, <i><span style=
'color:blue'>ritfr1</span></i>, <i><span style=
'color:blue'>ritfr2</span></i>, <i><span style=
'color:blue'>mi1</span></i>, and <i><span style=
'color:blue'>mi2</span></i> data is associated with the special
case&nbsp;involving an RUC with a separate
interface&nbsp;material&nbsp;(see Figure 3.5).&nbsp; Only those
RUCs shown in Figure 3.5 have the interface option available.&nbsp;
To specify one of these RUCs with an interface, simply include the
special case data shown in blue.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
7)&nbsp;&nbsp; Due to geometric constraints (i.e., adjacent fibers,
inclusions, or interfaces touching) each MAC/GMC 4.0 internal RUC
architecture&nbsp;has some restraints on its fiber volume
fraction&nbsp;(<i>vf</i>).&nbsp; These constraints are given for
each architecture in Table 3.3.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span style='font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046448"
id="_Toc23046448"></a><a name="_Toc26088623" id=

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046451"

"_Toc26088626">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 3c</b>, <b>Example 3e</b>, Example
5f, Example 7d, Example 7e</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046452"
id="_Toc23046452"></a><a name="_Toc26088627" id=
"_Toc26088627">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i><span style=
'color:blue'>modid</span></i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New";color:blue'>=1</span>
is a special case&nbsp;used in MAC/GMC 4.0 to select a monolithic
material.&nbsp; Internally, the code employs a double periodic GMC
RUC analysis&nbsp;with one subcell to which the material is
assigned using <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>M=</span></span><i>mm</i> (see
Example above).&nbsp; A monolithic material may also be selected by
using <i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=0</span></span>
in either doubly or triply periodic GMC.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; Doubly periodic HFGMC&nbsp;RUC
analysis&nbsp;requires an even number of subcells&nbsp;in both the
x<sub>2</sub>- and x<sub>3</sub>-directions and additional
specialized input under the <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar1">*SOLVER</span>
keyword.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>NA=</span><i><span style='color:blue'>na</span></i>
and <span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"; color:blue'>D=</span><i><span style='color:blue'>d(1),d(2)&hellip;,d(na)</span></i>
are only required in the special case&nbsp;of triply periodic RUC
analysis</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046453"
id="_Toc23046453"></a><a name="_Toc26088628" id=
"_Toc26088628">Additional Information:</a></h3>

<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 Keywords Manual Section 3
(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*LAMINATE</span></b></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 2</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046454"
id="_Toc23046454"></a><a name="_Toc26088629" id=
"_Toc26088629">*LAMINATE</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Laminate analysis and
architecture</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt; color:red'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'><a name=
"_Toc23046455" id="_Toc23046455"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Wingdings;color:red'>P</span>
<span style='color:red'>Either</span></a> <span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar"><span style=
'color:red'>*RUC</span></span> <span style='color:red'>or</span>
<span class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar"><span style=
'color:red'>*LAMINATE</span></span> <span style='color:red'>is
required in all input file</span><span style='color:red'>s</span>
<span style=
'font-size:14.0pt;font-family:Wingdings; color:red'>P</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc26088630"
id="_Toc26088630">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Invoke laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;(as opposed
to repeating unit cell analysis) for the problem, which requires
selection of a micromechanics&nbsp;model as well as specification
of an RUC architecture&nbsp;(i.e., arrangement of the composite
constituents) for the analysis of each each ply.&nbsp; Lastly, the
angle and thickness of each ply must be specified.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*LAMINATE</span></b></span>
section is broken into two sub-sections:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:9.0pt'>I. &nbsp; Layer RUC
Architecture from Internal Library (<i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char"><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>&NotEqual;99</span></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:9.0pt'>II. User-Defined
Layer RUC Architecture (<i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char"><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>=99</span></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#CCFFFF'>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'background:#CCFFFF;border:none;padding:0in'><b><span style=
'font-size:16.0pt;color:black'>I. Layer RUC Architecture from
Internal Library (<i>archid</i></span></b><b><span style=
'font-size:16.0pt;font-family: "Courier New";color:black'>&NotEqual;99</span></b><b><span style='font-size:16.0pt; color:black'>)</span></b></p>
</div>

<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i><span style=
'color:blue'>modid</span></i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New";color:blue'>=1</span>
is a special case&nbsp;used in MAC/GMC 4.0 to select a monolithic
layer.&nbsp; Internally, the code employs a double periodic GMC RUC
analysis&nbsp;for the layer with one subcell to which the material
is assigned using <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>M=</span></span><i>mm</i> (see
Example above).&nbsp; A monolithic material&nbsp;may also be
selected for a layer by using <i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=0</span></span>
in either doubly or triply periodic GMC.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The ability to employ triply periodic layers in a
laminate is new to version 4.0 of the code.&nbsp; Doubly periodic
HFGMC&nbsp;RUC analysis&nbsp;is not currently available for
laminate&nbsp;layers.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; Refer to the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*RUC</span></b></span>
description earlier in this section of this manual for the specific
input requirements for each RUC architecture.&nbsp; The RUC
architectures contained within the MAC/GMC 4.0 architecture
library&nbsp;are shown in Figure 3.4 (doubly periodic, no
interface), Figure 3.5 (doubly periodic, with interface), and
Figure 3.6 (triply periodic).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The <i><span style='color:blue'>ritfr</span></i> and
<i><span style='color:blue'>mi</span></i> data is associated with
the special case&nbsp;involving a layer&nbsp;with an RUC that has a
separate interface&nbsp;material&nbsp;(see Figure 3.5).&nbsp; Only
those RUCs shown in Figure 3.5 have the interface option
available.&nbsp; To specify one of these RUCs with an interface for
the layer, simply include the special case data shown in blue.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The
electromagnetic&nbsp;specifier&nbsp;(<span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>EM=</span><span class="normalitalicChar1Char"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>em</span></span>)
for the layer&nbsp;tells the code whether or not a particular layer
is electromagnetically active.&nbsp; This is only required in the
special case&nbsp;in which an electromagnetic analysis has been
selected by including the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*ELECROMAG</span></b></span>
keyword in the input file.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span style='font-size:2.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 7c</b></p>
<p class=

<span style='font-size:4.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046464"

"_Toc26088639">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:2.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i><span style=
'color:blue'>modid</span></i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New";color:blue'>=1</span>
is a special case&nbsp;used in MAC/GMC 4.0 to select a monolithic
layer.&nbsp; Internally, the code employs a double periodic GMC RUC
analysis&nbsp;for the layer with one subcell to which the material
is assigned using <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>M=</span></span><i>mm</i> (see
Example above).&nbsp; A monolithic material&nbsp;may also be
selected for a layer by using <i>archid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=0</span></span>
in either doubly or triply periodic GMC.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span style='font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; Doubly periodic HFGMC&nbsp;RUC analysis&nbsp;is not
currently available for laminate&nbsp;layers.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span style='font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The
electromagnetic&nbsp;specifier&nbsp;(<span style='font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>EM=</span><span class="normalitalicChar1Char"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>em</span></span>)
for the layer&nbsp;tells the code whether or not a particular layer
is electromagnetically active.&nbsp; This is only required in the
special case&nbsp;in which an electromagnetic analysis has been
selected by including the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*ELECROMAG</span></b></span>
keyword.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span style='font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i><span style=
'color:blue'>modid</span></i><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New";color:blue'>=NA</span>
and <span style=
'font-size:10.0pt; font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>D=</span><i><span style='color:blue'>d(1),d(2)&hellip;,d(na)</span></i>
are only required in the special case&nbsp;of triply periodic RUC

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=

<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 Keywords Manual Section 3
(<span class=

<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 3</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><br clear=
"all" style='page-break-before:auto'></span>
<div class="WordSection10">
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>
<h1 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;background:#E0E0E0'>
<a name="_Toc23046466" id="_Toc23046466"></a><a name="_Toc26088641"
id="_Toc26088641">Section 4 <span style='color:black'>: Loading
Keywords</span></a></h1>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This section presents the four MAC/GMC 4.0
keywords that are related to the applied loading.&nbsp; These
are:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*MECH</span> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Specify mechanical (and
electromagnetic) loading&nbsp;profile</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*THERM</span>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Specify thermal
loading&nbsp;profile</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*SOLVER</span>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Specify
time-integration&nbsp;data</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1CharChar">*SURF</span> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Specify loading&nbsp;(and
additional information) for yield&nbsp;surface analysis</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Because MAC/GMC 4.0 allows for inelastic
material behavior, the simulated loading&nbsp;must be applied in an
incremental manner.&nbsp; The problem solutions are (in general)
path-dependent, so the overall solution (at the completion of the
applied loading) actually involves solving the problem at each
increment of the simulated applied loading.&nbsp; As such, a
simulated loading <i>profile</i> must be specified rather than just
the final load levels.&nbsp; The loading profile is essentially a
load vs. time history that MAC/GMC 4.0 will apply to the specified
RUC or laminate.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">For repeating unit cell analysis, mechanical
loading&nbsp;takes the form of an admissible time profile for each
of the six global (stress or strain) components present in the RUC
constitutive equation.&nbsp; For example, consider the standard
(non-electromagnetic) repeating unit cell effective constitutive
equation,</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style='text-align:center'>
<span style='position:relative;top:52.0pt'><img border="0" width=
"192" height="147" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image065.png"></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">where <span style=
'position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width="21" height=
"25" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image066.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) stress components on the composite,
<span style='position:relative; top:3.0pt'><img border="0" width=
"20" height="21" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image067.png"></span>&nbsp;is
the global (or effective) stiffness matrix, <span style=
'position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width="19" height=
"25" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image068.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) normal strain components on the composite,
<span style='position: relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width=
"19" height="25" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image069.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) engineering shear strain&nbsp;components on
the composite, <span style=
'position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width="21" height=
"27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image070.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) normal inelastic strain components on the
composite, <span style='position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border=
"0" width="24" height="27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image071.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) engineering shear inelastic strain
components on the composite, <span style=
'position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width="21" height=
"27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image072.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) normal thermal strain components on the
composite, and <span style=
'position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width="21" height=
"27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image073.png"></span>&nbsp;are
the global (or average) engineering shear thermal strain components
on the composite.&nbsp; Admissibility simply requires that, if a
particular strain component is specified, the corresponding stress
component cannot be specified (and vice versa).&nbsp; In addition
to the arbitrary mechanical loading&nbsp;option&nbsp;(which allows
the user to specify all six loading components, MAC/GMC 4.0 also
includes several internal loading options that simplify the
application of loading for commonly used mechanical loading
types.&nbsp; In the special case&nbsp;of electromagnetic&nbsp;RUC
analysis, the number of loading components is increased from six to
twelve to accommodate applied electric and magnetic load components
(see the MAC/GMC 4.0 Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 2.1.2).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The applied mechanical loading&nbsp;for
laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;is different than that of RUC
analysis.&nbsp; Globally, rather than dealing with average stresses
and strains, the applicable quantities are stress and moment
resultants along with midplane strains and curvatures (see the
MAC/GMC 4.0 Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 3).&nbsp; For laminate
analysis, the code&CloseCurlyQuote;s internal mechanical
loading&nbsp;options are numbered differently than those associated
with RUC mechanical loading.&nbsp; As is the case in
electromagnetic&nbsp;RUC analysis, electromagnetic laminate
analysis involves additional electromagnetic loading
components.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">MAC/GMC 4.0 also allows application of a
simulated time vs. temperature&nbsp;profile for both RUC and
laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;using the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>
keyword.&nbsp; It should be noted that the temperature at every
point in time is treated as constant throughout the RUC or
laminate; the code does not solve any thermal boundary value
problems, but rather treats the temperature history as known.&nbsp;
The <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*SOLVER</span></b></span> keyword
is used to select either a constant time step forward
Euler&nbsp;time integration&nbsp;scheme, or a
self-adaptive&nbsp;predictor-corrector time
integration&nbsp;scheme.&nbsp; Finally, the yield&nbsp;surface
option keyword (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*SURF</span></b></span>)
is a special case&nbsp;in that the yield surface
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;probing&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; (i.e.,
loading&nbsp;along different angles in a particular stress space)
controls the applied loading.&nbsp; In this case, the data
specified under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span>,
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>, and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*SOLVER</span></b></span> are
considered to be a
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;preload&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; that occurs
before the start of the yield surface analysis.&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</div>

<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046467"
id="_Toc23046467"></a><a name="_Toc26088642" id=
"_Toc26088642">*MECH</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Applied mechanical loading</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046468"
id="_Toc23046468"></a><a name="_Toc26088643" id=
"_Toc26088643">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Specify the simulated mechanical (and
electromagnetic) loading&nbsp;profile for the RUC or laminate.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046469"
id="_Toc23046469"></a><a name="_Toc26088644" id=
"_Toc26088644">Usage:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*MECH</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
<span style='color:black'>&nbsp; LOP=</span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>lop</span></span>
<span style='color:blue'>REFTIME=</span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>reftime</span></span></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
<span style='color:black'>&nbsp; NPT=</span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>npt</span></span>
<span style='color:black'>TI=</span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>t(1),t(2),&hellip;,t(npt)</span></span>

<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:46.75pt;text-indent:-46.75pt'><span style=
'font-family:Wingdings'>F</span> <u>Note:</u>&nbsp;&nbsp;
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>s</span><sub>ij</sub> = stress,

engineering shear strain, N<sub>ij</sub> = force resultant,
M<sub>ij</sub> = moment resultant, <span style=
'position:relative;top:7.0pt'><img border="0" width="17" height=
"27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image082.png"></span>&nbsp;=
midplane strains, &kappa;<sub>ij</sub> = midplane curvatures,
D<sub>k</sub> = electrical displacements, E<sub>k</sub> = electric
fields, B<sub>k</sub> = magnetic flux densities, H<sub>k</sub> =
magnetic fields.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:46.75pt;text-indent:-46.75pt'>&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046471"
id="_Toc23046471"></a><a name="_Toc26088646" id=
"_Toc26088646">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Example 1c-d, Example 2a-h, Example 3a-i,
<b>Example 4a</b>, <b>Example 4b</b>, <b>Example 4c</b>, <b>Example
4d</b>, Example 4e, Example 5b-f, Example 6a-b, Example 7a,
<b>Example 7b</b>, <b>Example 7c</b></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046472"
id="_Toc23046472"></a><a name="_Toc26088647" id=
"_Toc26088647">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><u><span style=
'font-family:"Arial",sans-serif'>&nbsp;</span></u></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; As shown in Table 4.1, certain values of <i>lop</i>
are invalid in certain cases.&nbsp; In particular,
<i>lop</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=11</span></span>
and <i>lop</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=12</span></span>
are only valid for triply periodic RUC analysis, while for
laminate&nbsp;analysis, the only valid values for lop are
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family: "Courier New"'>1&ndash;6</span> and
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New"'>99</span>.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The optional&nbsp;<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;font-family:"Courier New";color:blue'>REFTIME=</span><i><span style='color:blue'>reftime</span></i>
specifier is used to set a reference strain value other than
zero.&nbsp; The reference strain is the strain value that all the
rest of the specified loading&nbsp;strain values are taken with
respect to.&nbsp; For example, if the reference strain were 0.015,
and a strain load of 0.01 were specified, the code would increase
the strain to 0.025.&nbsp; Instead of specifying the reference
strain directly, a time is given at which the strain state is taken
as the six reference strain components.&nbsp; This feature is
useful when simulating residual&nbsp;stresses prior to applying
loading in the form of strains (see MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem
4b).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The first time specified for each mechanical (and
electromagnetic) loading&nbsp;component must be zero, and the final
time for each component must be the same.&nbsp; However, the number
of intermediate times, as well as the intermediate times
themselves, can be different for each applied loading
component.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The units&nbsp;of the applied loading&nbsp;should be
consistent with the units employed for the constituent
materials.&nbsp; That is, for example, if the units of the
constituent material elastic moduli are MPa, any applied stress
components will be interpreted by the code as having the units
MPa.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The first specified load magnitude&nbsp;should be
zero.&nbsp; The code must begin its execution&nbsp;in an unloaded
state.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
6)&nbsp;&nbsp; In the special case&nbsp;of an electromagnetically
active&nbsp;laminate, the
electromagnetic&nbsp;loading&nbsp;currently can only take the form
of applied electric field&nbsp;components (<i>E<sub>k</sub></i>)
and magnetic field&nbsp;(<i>H<sub>k</sub></i>) components.&nbsp;
That is, laminate electric displacement&nbsp;(<i>D<sub>k</sub></i>)
and magnetic flux density&nbsp;(<i>B<sub>k</sub></i>) components
cannot currently be applied.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>

<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=

<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Only two choices are currently available, thus

<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>II.

<p class="MsoNormal">Example 1c-d, Example 2a-h, Example 3a-i,
Example 4a-f, Example 5b-f, Example 6a-c, Example 7a-c</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046486"
id="_Toc23046486"></a><a name="_Toc26088661" id=
"_Toc26088661">Note:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; The starting time&nbsp;in the time vs. step
size&nbsp;profile must be zero.&nbsp; The ending time&nbsp;must
correspond to the ending time of any mechanical and thermal
loading&nbsp;specified under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span> and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>.&nbsp;
The ending time must correspond to the ending time of any
mechanical and thermal loading&nbsp;specified under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span> and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>.&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The forward Euler&nbsp;integration&nbsp;scheme
involves stepping through time with a <u>specified time step
size</u>.&nbsp; At each time step, increments of the field
variables&nbsp;throughout the RUC or laminate&nbsp;are calculated
and simply added to the previous field variable values.&nbsp; The
user specifies a number of time points along with the time step
size to be used between each successive time point (see Example
above).&nbsp; If the time step is too large, the time
integration&nbsp;can diverge, which leads to oscillations or
overflow in the results&nbsp;(see Example Problem 7a). The maximum
permissible time step size that still allows convergence is problem
dependent; users are encouraged to experiment with this value for
their problems of interest.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>ITMAX=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>itmax</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>and</span></span>
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>ERR=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>errtol</span></span>
are required only in the special case&nbsp;when one or more
constituent material is modeled a) using classical incremental
plasticity&nbsp;(<i>cmod</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=21</span></span>)
or b) implicit
multimechanism&nbsp;GVIPS&nbsp;(<i>cmod</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=22</span></span>).&nbsp;
These two constitutive models require iterations (at each increment
of the applied loading) to ensure that global equilibrium&nbsp;is
satisfied.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span style=
'font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:31.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>a)&nbsp; In the case of
incremental plasticity, to quantify convergence of the global
iterations, MAC/GMC 4.0 employs the local effective plastic strain
increment as a measure of the error.&nbsp; Convergence is achieved
when the fractional change of the effective plastic strain
increment from one iteration&nbsp;to the next is less than
<i>errtol</i> throughout the RUC or laminate.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span style=
'font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style=
'margin-left:31.5pt;text-indent:-13.5pt'>b) In the case of implicit
multimechanism&nbsp;GVIPS, a global energy related increment is
employed as a measure of error.&nbsp; Convergence is achieved when
the fractional change of this increment from one iteration&nbsp;to
the next is less than <i>errtol</i>. &nbsp;The acceptable value of
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>errtol</span></span> is
problem dependent.&nbsp; Users are encouraged to experiment with
this value for their specific problems of interest.&nbsp; Note that
this constitutive model&nbsp;employs a local implicit
integration&nbsp;scheme internally.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>NLEG=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>nleg</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>and</span></span>
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>NINTEG=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>nint</span></span>
are required only in the special case&nbsp;of doubly periodic RUC
analysis&nbsp;using HFGMC&nbsp;(<i>modid</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=12</span></span>).&nbsp;
In this case, the inelastic strain field can vary arbitrarily
throughout the RUC.&nbsp; In order&nbsp;to represent the inelastic
strain field in HFGMC, MAC/GMC 4.0 employs
Legendre&nbsp;polynomials, the order of which must be
specified.&nbsp; In addition, the number of
integration&nbsp;points&nbsp;at which all field variables&nbsp;are
tracked must be specified.&nbsp; <i><span style=
'color:blue'>nint</span></i> is the number of integration points
for both the <i>x<sub>2</sub></i>- and
<i>x<sub>3</sub></i>-directions per subcell.&nbsp; Thus, for
example, if <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>NINTEG=11</span></span>
is specified, 11 integration points are used per subcell in each of
the two direction, for a total of 121 integration points for each
subcell.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The values <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>NLEG=5</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>&nbsp;</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family: "Times New Roman",serif;font-style:normal'>and</span></span>
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>NINTEG=11</span></span>&nbsp;have
been shown to yield&nbsp;good precision in the local fields
predicted by HFGMC.&nbsp; These values should be employed as
default values unless the user is confident in using other
values.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
<span style='font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>

id="_Toc23046489"></a><a name="_Toc26088664" id=
"_Toc26088664">Example:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
*SOLVER</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>&nbsp;
METHOD=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>2
ISTM=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.001
ISTT=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.1
ERR=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.001
MINSTEP=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.00001</span></span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046490"
id="_Toc23046490"></a><a name="_Toc26088665" id=
"_Toc26088665">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 4h</b></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046491"
id="_Toc23046491"></a><a name="_Toc26088666" id=
"_Toc26088666">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; The self-adaptive&nbsp;predictor-corrector
integration&nbsp;scheme <u>cannot</u> currently be utilized in
conjunction with the following features:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:27.0pt'>a)&nbsp;
Laminate&nbsp;analysis&nbsp;(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*LAMINATE</span></b></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:27.0pt'>b)
Fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DAMAGE</span></b></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:27.0pt'>c)&nbsp; Classical
incremental plasticity&nbsp;(<i>cmod</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=21</span></span>)</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:27.0pt'>d) Implicit
multimechanism&nbsp;GVIPS&nbsp;(<i>cmod</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>=22</span></span>).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The self-adaptive&nbsp;predictor-corrector
integration&nbsp;scheme employs a
fourth-order&nbsp;Runge-Kutta&nbsp;starter, an
Adams-Bashforth&nbsp;four-step predictor, and an Adams-Moulton four
step corrector (see the MAC/GMC 4.0 Theory Manual&nbsp;Section
7.2).&nbsp; It starts with a small time step that is permitted to
increase, provided the error&nbsp;remains within acceptable
limits.&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>ISTM=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>istm</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black;font-style:normal'>
and</span></span> <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>ISTT=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>istt</span></span>
are used to specify the initial (starting) time step sizes for
mechanical and thermal loading.&nbsp; These are independent
variables because the time scale is often vastly different for
mechanical and thermal loading.&nbsp; The code chooses the
appropriate initial time step&nbsp;size from <i>istm</i> and
<i>istt</i> based on whether the initial applied loading (specified
under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span> and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char1">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>)
involves any change in the mechanical or thermal load levels.&nbsp;
If the mechanical and thermal load levels are both initially
changing, the code will choose the smaller of <i>istm</i> and
<i>istt</i>.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>ERR=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>errtol</span></span>
specifies the acceptable fractional difference between predicted
and corrected values of the field variables.&nbsp; If the
fractional difference between these values for any field variable
in any subcell is greater than <i>errtol</i>, the time step
size&nbsp;will be cut in half.&nbsp; Otherwise, the time step size
will be permitted to double, provided the history of each field
variable required for prediction using the larger time step has
been stored.&nbsp; An <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'>errtol</span></span> value of
0.001 can be used as starting point, but an acceptable value can be
problem dependent.&nbsp; Users are encouraged to experiment with
this value for their problems of interest.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>MINSTEP=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>minstp</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black;font-style:normal'>
is used to prevent the time step from becoming too small.&nbsp; In
some cases changing</span></span> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>minstep</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black;font-style:normal'>
to a larger value can significantly decrease
execution</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;time
(i.e., speed up the execution) without compromising the accuracy of
the code&CloseCurlyQuote;s results</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>

<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2><a name="_Toc23046493" id="_Toc23046493"></a><a name=
"_Toc26088668" id="_Toc26088668">*SURF</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style='font-size:14.0pt'>Yield
Surface Analysis</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'><a name=
"_Toc23046494" id="_Toc23046494"><span style=
'font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></a></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc26088669"
id="_Toc26088669">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Generate RUC or
laminate&nbsp;yield&nbsp;surfaces.</p>
