<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046497"
id="_Toc23046497"></a><a name="_Toc26088672" id=
"_Toc26088672">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:5.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 4f</b>, <b>Example 4g</b></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046498"
id="_Toc23046498"></a><a name="_Toc26088673" id=
"_Toc26088673">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0 generates yield&nbsp;surfaces by
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;probing&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; in a
particular stress space until all yield criteria&nbsp;are
satisfied.&nbsp; Probing involves applying multi-axial
loading&nbsp;such that the angle in the specified stress space
remains constant.&nbsp; For example, if the <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>11</sub>-<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>22</sub> stress space were
specified, probing at an angle of 45<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&deg;</span> would involve incremental
application of <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>11</sub> = <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>22</sub> until all yield criteria
were satisfied.&nbsp; Probing at an angle of 30<span style=
'font-family: Symbol'>&deg;</span> would involve application of
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>22</sub> =
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>11</sub>
tan(30<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&deg;</span>)&nbsp; until
all yield criteria were satisfied.&nbsp; When all angles from
0<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&deg;</span> to 360<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&deg;</span> are probed and the stresses at
which yield is detected are recorded, the yield surface can be
plotted from the data files generated by the code.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; The loading&nbsp;for
yield&nbsp;surface analysis is controlled under the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*SURF</span></b></span>
keyword.&nbsp; This loading must be isothermal and always employs
the forward Euler&nbsp;time integration&nbsp;scheme.&nbsp; In
addition, the loading cannot be divided into separate portions with
different time step sizes.&nbsp; Any loading information that is
specified using <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span>,
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>, and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*SOLVER</span></b></span> is
treated as a
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;preload&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;.&nbsp; This
preload is applied prior to the start of the yield surface
probing&nbsp;and thus can be used to generate yield surfaces that
incorporate residual&nbsp;stresses.&nbsp; <i>tmax</i> and
<i>mmax</i> are the time and load magnitude&nbsp;at which yield
surface probing will stop regardless of whether or not all yield
surface criteria have been satisfied.&nbsp; Thus, if the code
reaches this loading end point at a particular probing angle, the
yield surface data for one or more plots will not be valid at this
angle, and a warning will be written to the output&nbsp;file.&nbsp;
It is therefore desirable to make the loading end point large so
that yielding can always occur before the end point is
reached.&nbsp; The code automatically stops probing at a particular
angle when all yield criteria&nbsp;are satisfied, so employing
large <i>tmax</i> and <i>mmax</i> values will not adversely affect
execution&nbsp;time.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Note that in order&nbsp;to
generalize the specified loading&nbsp;for the multi-axial loading
required for yield&nbsp;surface probing, the specified loading
(<i>mmax)</i> is interpreted as an invariant quantity.&nbsp; In
particular, for stress and force resultant&nbsp;control,
<i>mmax</i> is interpreted as <span style=
'position:relative;top:6.0pt'><img border="0" width="33" height=
"27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image086.png"></span>, while
for strain control <i>mmax</i> is interpreted as <span style=
'position:relative; top:6.0pt'><img border="0" width="33" height=
"27" src=
"MAC-GMC-4.0-Keywords-Manual-6_files/image087.png"></span>.&nbsp;
This allows the loading to be applied at a constant equivalent
rate, regardless of probing angle.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>TREF=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>tref</span></span>
is required in the special case&nbsp;that no thermal preloading has
been specified.&nbsp; If thermal preloading is specified (using
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span>), the
code assumes that the yield&nbsp;surface probing&nbsp;occurs at the
ending temperature&nbsp;of the thermal preload.&nbsp; In the
absence of thermal preloading, the code requires <i><span style=
'color:blue'>tref</span></i> to specify the temperature for yield
surface probing.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The yield&nbsp;surface options are given in Table
4.2.&nbsp; At least one option must be specified and up to four may
be specified for RUC yield surface analysis.&nbsp; For
laminate&nbsp;yield surfaces, up to seven options may be
specified.&nbsp; Each yield surface option specified will cause a
data file to be generated.&nbsp; This data file will contain the
probing&nbsp;angle and the global stress state at which yielding
was detected at that probing angle for each of the four yield
surface types (<i>eps, dr, isr, ip</i>).&nbsp; In the case of
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>OPTION=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>4</span></span>
or <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>OPTION=7</span></span>, all of this
data will be repeated for each individual ply&nbsp;or each
individual subcell.&nbsp; Note that elastic subcells will be
skipped.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The x and y stress space specifiers (<i>ispx(j),
ispy(j)</i>) are used indicate to the code which
loading&nbsp;components&nbsp;will be applied to generate the
yield&nbsp;surface.&nbsp; <i>ispx(1)</i> and <i>ispy(1 )</i>are
required.&nbsp; These are the controlling components that will
occupy the x- and y- axes on the plot of the yield surface.&nbsp;
Two optional&nbsp;slave components (<i><span style=
'color:blue'>ispx(2)</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>ispx(3)</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>ispy(2)</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>ispy(3)</span></i>) may be specified for each of the
controlling components.&nbsp; The slave components will be loaded
to the same value as the corresponding controlling
components.&nbsp; For example, if <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>11</sub> and <span style=
'font-family: Symbol'>s</span><sub>22</sub> were specified as the x
and y controlling components and <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>33</sub> were specified as a
slave y component (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>ISPX=</span></span><span class="Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>1
ISPY=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>2,3</span></span>),
at a probing&nbsp;angle of 30<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&deg;</span>, <span style=
'font-family: Symbol'>s</span><sub>33</sub> = <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>22</sub> = <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>s</span><sub>11</sub> tan(30<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&deg;</span>) would be incrementally
applied.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; Note that for
laminate&nbsp;yield&nbsp;surfaces, <i>ispx(i)</i> and
<i>ispy(i)</i> can only take the values 1, 2, or 3, corresponding
to in-plane loading.&nbsp; Thus, at most one slave
component&nbsp;can be specified.&nbsp; Further, the yield surface
analysis is only valid for symmetric laminates with no bending.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>

and output</span><span style=
'font-weight:normal'>&nbsp;file</span><span style=
'font-weight:normal'>&nbsp;names for RUC and
laminate</span><span style=
'font-weight:normal'>&nbsp;analyses.</span></p>

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc26088674"
id="_Toc26088674">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:4.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 6</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><br clear=
"all" style='page-break-before:auto'></span>
<div class="WordSection12">
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>
<h1 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;background:#E0E0E0'>
<a name="_Toc23046500" id="_Toc23046500"></a><a name="_Toc26088675"
id="_Toc26088675">Section 5 <span style='color:black'>: Damage and
Failure Keywords</span></a></h1>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This section deals with the six MAC/GMC 4.0
keywords that enable analysis of damage&nbsp;and failure&nbsp;in
composites materials and laminates.&nbsp; These are:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*ALLOWABLES</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span> Elastic estimation
of the composite allowables</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*FAILURE_SUBCELL</span></b></span> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Subcell level static
failure&nbsp;analysis</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*FAILURE_CELL</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> RUC level static
failure&nbsp;analysis</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DAMAGE</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span> Cyclic
fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DEBOND</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span> Internal
fiber-matrix interfacial&nbsp;debonding</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*CURTIN</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span>
Curtin&nbsp;effective fiber breakage&nbsp;model for longitudinal
fiber failure</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Elastic allowables&nbsp;estimation is the
simplest form of failure&nbsp;analysis available in MAC/GMC
4.0.&nbsp; Composite (RUC) allowable stress components are
estimated based on the global level of each individual stress
component that causes the allowable stress in a constituent
material to be met.&nbsp; The composite allowable strain components
are similarly estimated.&nbsp; These calculations are easily
performed via the GMC concentration equations&nbsp;and are
independent of any simulated loading&nbsp;applied to the
composite.&nbsp; As such, the estimated allowables are like
material properties&nbsp;for the specified RUC because altering the
applied loading (e.g., adding simulated residual&nbsp;stresses)
does not have an effect.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Static failure&nbsp;analysis within MAC/GMC
4.0 (via the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*FAILURE_SUBCELL</span></b></span> and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*FAILURE_CELL</span></b></span>
keywords) is completely different from the
allowables&nbsp;estimation.&nbsp; The static failure&nbsp;analysis
monitors the stress and strain components in the composite or
laminate&nbsp;(on the subcell or RUC level) and checks for failures
using the specified failure criteria.&nbsp; Thus, the static
failure analysis (like an actual experimental test) is inherently
linked to the loading&nbsp;applied to the RUC or laminate and the
predicted failure stress and strain are not truly material
properties.&nbsp; That is, for example, a uni-axial tensile test on
a highly strain rate dependent metallic alloy performed at a strain
rate of 10<sup>-2</sup> per second would result in a completely
different measured strength than that resulting from the same test
on the same alloy performed at a strain rate of 10<sup>-6</sup> per
second.&nbsp; Clearly, the strength measured for this material is
not a material property, but is linked to the loading conditions to
which the material is subjected.&nbsp; Static failure analysis
within MAC/GMC 4.0 is the same way.&nbsp; The allowables estimation
is a quick and simple first pass at predicting composite failure
stresses and strains from the constituent allowables.&nbsp; For
more realistic failure analyses, the static failure capabilities
within MAC/GMC 4.0 should be employed.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The final three keywords covered in this
section deal with more specialized damage&nbsp;and
failure&nbsp;analysis techniques.&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DAMAGE</span></b></span> enables
use of a simple strength reduction&nbsp;model (typically applied to
the fiber constituent) and a more complex stiffness
reduction&nbsp;model (typically applied to the matrix constituent)
for composites and laminates subjected to
cyclic&nbsp;loading.&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DEBOND</span></b></span> allows
the effect of local fiber-matrix debonding, which is prevalent in
some composites (most notably titanium matrix composites), to be
included within RUC and laminate&nbsp;analyses.&nbsp; Finally, the
Curtin&nbsp;effective fiber breakage&nbsp;model (<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*CURTIN</span></b></span>)
is an approach based on fiber strength&nbsp;statistics that account
for the longitudinal stiffness reduction due to failure of fibers
in RUCs and laminates.</p>
</div>
<span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><br clear=
"all" style='page-break-before:auto'></span>
<div class="WordSection13">
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046501"
id="_Toc23046501"></a><a name="_Toc26088676" id=
"_Toc26088676">*ALLOWABLES</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Estimated elastic allowables</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style='text-align:center'>
<span style='font-family:Wingdings;color:red'>N</span><span style=
'font-family:"Tahoma",sans-serif; color:red'>&nbsp;
Caution&nbsp;</span> <span style=
'font-family:Wingdings;color:red'>N</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style='text-align:center'>
<span style='font-family:"Tahoma",sans-serif;color:red'>These
estimated allowables</span><span style=
'font-family:"Tahoma",sans-serif;color:red'>&nbsp;should not be
considered &OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;design
allowables</span><span style=
'font-family:"Tahoma",sans-serif;color:red'>&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote;,
which by definition have been extensively validated with
experimental data</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" align="center" style='text-align:center'>
<span style=
'font-family:"Tahoma",sans-serif;color:red'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046502"
id="_Toc23046502"></a><a name="_Toc26088677" id=
"_Toc26088677">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Estimate the composite allowables&nbsp;based
on the allowables of the constituent materials and linear
elastic&nbsp;concentration calculations.&nbsp; MAC/GMC 4.0
calculates three sets of elastic stress and strain allowable
components, listed in order&nbsp;from most to least
conservative:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>First Subcell Allowables</i> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Global stress/strain at which the
first subcell&nbsp;reaches its allowable stress/strain level</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>Average Material Allowables</i> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Global stress/strain at which the
average material&nbsp;stress/strain for one of the constituents
reaches its allowable stress/strain level</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; <i>All Subcells Allowables</i> <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Global stress/strain at which all
of the subcells have reached their allowable stress/strain
levels</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Each allowable component is estimated based
purely on a linear elastic&nbsp;concentration calculation involving
application of a single global stress or strain component.&nbsp;
Three separate sets of allowables are provided, an upper bound (all
subcells&nbsp;allowables), lower bound (first
subcell&nbsp;allowables), and an intermediate set (average
material&nbsp;allowables), thus enabling the user to make a
judicious choice based on the specific problem of interest.&nbsp;
Note that the allowables&nbsp;estimation is available for RUC
analysis&nbsp;only (not laminate&nbsp;analysis).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046503"
id="_Toc23046503"></a><a name="_Toc26088678" id=
"_Toc26088678">Usage:</a></h3>

<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*ALLOWABLES</p>

"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0.005</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046505"
id="_Toc23046505"></a><a name="_Toc26088680" id=
"_Toc26088680">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 5a</b>, Example 5b</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046506"
id="_Toc23046506"></a><a name="_Toc26088681" id=
"_Toc26088681">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; If a constituent material that is present in the RUC
does not have allowables&nbsp;specified, the subcells that contain
this material will not be considered in the allowables
estimation.&nbsp; In such a case, the All Subcells Allowables will
still be calculated by skipping the subcells containing the
material in question.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; If a particular component is omitted from either the
stress or strain allowables&nbsp;input for a particular material,
that component will not be considered in the calculation for
subcells containing that particular material.&nbsp; If none of the
materials within the RUC have an allowable specified for a
particular component, an allowable will not be calculated for that
component.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The specified shear strain allowables&nbsp;are
interpreted by the code as engineering shear strains.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The compressive stress and strain
allowables&nbsp;(<i><span style='color:blue'>sc11</span>,
<span style='color:blue'>sc22</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>sc33</span>, <span style='color:blue'>ec11</span>,
<span style='color:blue'>ec22</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>ec33</span></i>) are only required in the special
case&nbsp;when the compression specifier (<i>comprs</i> or
<i>compre</i>) <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>=DIF</span></span>.&nbsp; Otherwise,
the compressive stress and strain allowables&nbsp;should be
omitted.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046507"
id="_Toc23046507"></a><a name="_Toc26088682" id=
"_Toc26088682">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.1</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046508"
id="_Toc23046508"></a><a name="_Toc26088683" id=
"_Toc26088683">*FAILURE_SUBCELL</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Subcell static failure</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></h2>
</div>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046509"
id="_Toc23046509"></a><a name="_Toc26088684" id=
"_Toc26088684">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Perform static failure&nbsp;analysis based on
the local stress and strain fields in the subcells.&nbsp; Static
failure&nbsp;analysis involves checking the specified failure
criteria&nbsp;during application of a simulated thermo-mechanical
loading&nbsp;history.&nbsp; This is distinct from the
allowables&nbsp;estimation, which is a linear
elastic&nbsp;concentration calculation independent of the applied
loading&nbsp;and any material history dependence.&nbsp; Thus, while
the allowables may be considered predicted material
properties&nbsp;for a composite, the static failure predictions are
inherently linked to the specifics of the simulated loading applied
to the composite.&nbsp; The maximum stress, maximum strain, and
Tsai-Hill&nbsp;failure criteria are available within MAC/GMC
4.0.&nbsp; This availability, however, does not imply endorsement
of these criteria by any parties associated with the code.&nbsp;
The static failure analysis capabilities should be used with
caution.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046510"
id="_Toc23046510"></a><a name="_Toc26088685" id=
"_Toc26088685">Usage:</a></h3>

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046512"
id="_Toc23046512"></a><a name="_Toc26088687" id=
"_Toc26088687">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 5b</b>, Example 5c, Example 5d</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046513"
id="_Toc23046513"></a><a name="_Toc26088688" id=
"_Toc26088688">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; If a constituent material that is present in the RUC
does not have subcell failure&nbsp;parameters specified, the
subcells that contain this material will not be considered when
checking for failure&nbsp;(i.e., they are treated as infinitely
strong).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; If a particular component (<i>xij</i>) is omitted
from the failure&nbsp;parameters for either the maximum
stress&nbsp;or maximum strain&nbsp;criterion, that component will
not be considered when checking for failure of subcells containing
that particular material.&nbsp; For the Tsai-Hill&nbsp;criterion,
all of the components (<i>xij</i>) are required.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; In the case of the maximum strain&nbsp;criterion,
the specified shear failure&nbsp;strains are interpreted by the
code as engineering shear strains.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The compression specifier (<i><span style=
'color:blue'>compr</span></i>) and the compressive
failure&nbsp;parameters (<i><span style='color:blue'>xc11</span>,
<span style='color:blue'>xc22</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>xc33</span></i>) are not required for the
Tsai-Hill&nbsp;criterion.&nbsp; The compressive failure parameters
(<i><span style='color:blue'>xc11</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>xc22</span>, <span style='color:blue'>xc33</span></i>)
are only required for the maximum stress&nbsp;and maximum
strain&nbsp;criteria in the special case&nbsp;when the compression
specifier <i>compr</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>=DIF</span></span>.&nbsp;
Otherwise, the compressive failure parameters should be
omitted.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>ACTION=</span></span><i>action</i>
is ignored in the case of fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis
(<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DAMAGE</span></b></span>)
and can be omitted in that case.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046514"
id="_Toc23046514"></a><a name="_Toc26088689" id=
"_Toc26088689">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.2</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046515"
id="_Toc23046515"></a><a name="_Toc26088690" id=
"_Toc26088690">*FAILURE_CELL</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Repeating unit cell static

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046516"
id="_Toc23046516"></a><a name="_Toc26088691" id=
"_Toc26088691">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Perform static failure&nbsp;analysis based on
the RUC level stress and strain fields.&nbsp; As with subcell level
static failure&nbsp;analysis, RUC level static failure analysis
involves checking the specified failure criteria&nbsp;during
application of a simulated thermo-mechanical
loading&nbsp;history.&nbsp; Thus, the RUC level static failure
predictions are inherently linked to the specifics of the simulated
loading&nbsp;applied to the composite.&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>

'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; If a particular component (<i>xij</i>) is omitted
from the failure&nbsp;parameters for either the maximum
stress&nbsp;or maximum strain&nbsp;criterion, that component will
not be considered when checking for failure of the RUC.&nbsp; For
the Tsai-Hill&nbsp;criterion, all of the components (<i>xij</i>)
are required.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The specified shear strain allowables&nbsp;are
interpreted by the code as engineering shear strains.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The compression specifier (<i><span style=
'color:blue'>compr</span></i>) and the compressive
failure&nbsp;parameters (<i><span style='color:blue'>xc11</span>,
<span style='color:blue'>xc22</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>xc33</span></i>) are not required for the
Tsai-Hill&nbsp;criterion.&nbsp; The compressive failure parameters
(<i><span style='color:blue'>xc11</span>, <span style=
'color:blue'>xc22</span>, <span style='color:blue'>xc33</span></i>)
are only required for the maximum stress&nbsp;and maximum
strain&nbsp;criteria in the special case&nbsp;when the compression
specifier <i>compr</i><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>=DIF</span></span>.&nbsp;
Otherwise, the compressive failure parameters should be
omitted.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2CharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:black'>ACTION=</span></span><i>action</i>
is ignored in the case of fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis (when
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DAMAGE</span></b></span> is
included in the input file) and can be omitted in that case.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046521"
id="_Toc23046521"></a><a name="_Toc26088696" id=
"_Toc26088696">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.2</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046522"
id="_Toc23046522"></a><a name="_Toc26088697" id=
"_Toc26088697">*DAMAGE</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Fatigue damage</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;analysis</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046523"
id="_Toc23046523"></a><a name="_Toc26088698" id=
"_Toc26088698">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Perform fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis on
an RUC or laminate.&nbsp; The damage related applied
loading&nbsp;information and constituent material damage parameters
are also specified under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*DAMAGE</span></b></span>.&nbsp;
MAC/GMC 4.0 contains two fatigue damage models.&nbsp; The first is
a simple strength reduction&nbsp;model, which allows for a
specified semi-logarithmic&nbsp;degradation of material strength,
typically applied to fiber constituents.&nbsp; The second is a more
involved stiffness reduction&nbsp;model (the Anisotropic Damage
Evolution and Life Model, which reduces to the ONERA&nbsp;NonLinear
Cumulative Damage Rule when the material is isotropic), which has a
number of material parameters that are characterized based on
material S-N curves (see Arnold and Kruch, 1994).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">In traditional fatigue&nbsp;tests on
materials, a given loading&nbsp;cycle&nbsp;is applied repeatedly to
a material until failure&nbsp;occurs.&nbsp; The fatigue life of the
material is then the number of cycles to failure for a given
cyclic&nbsp;loading profile.&nbsp; For composite materials, the GMC
micromechanics&nbsp;models implemented within MAC/GMC 4.0 are ideal
for fatigue damage&nbsp;analysis because of the availability of the
micro scale (subcell level) fields enables stress
redistribution&nbsp;during fatigue simulations.&nbsp; That is, for
example, if a cyclic fatigue load of 0 to 50 ksi&nbsp;is imposed on
a virgin composite material specimen, the fiber and matrix will
each experience a certain multiaxial stress state at the maximum
load level of 50 ksi.&nbsp; However, after a number of cycles,
matrix damage may cause a local stiffness reduction.&nbsp;
Consequently, during subsequent cycles, the fiber stress will
increase due to the loss of load carrying capacity in the
matrix.&nbsp; This type of stress redistribution cannot be
accounted for using macro scale fatigue approaches (i.e., treating
the composite as a homogenized effective material) in conjunction
with Basquin&CloseCurlyQuote;s Law or the Coffin-Manson Law.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Explicitly simulating fatigue&nbsp;tests to
account for the stress redistribution&nbsp;by repeatedly
executing&nbsp;a model to evaluate the damage&nbsp;for every cycle
can quickly become computationally intensive.&nbsp; This is
particularly true in the present case of inelastic
micromechanics&nbsp;where the loading&nbsp;for each cycle must be
applied incrementally, and a good number of local field and state
variables&nbsp;must be tracked for each subcell.&nbsp; The fatigue
damage analysis within MAC/GMC 4.0 avoids this computationally
demanding explicit type of analysis by solving the inverse
problem.&nbsp; Rather than applying a loading cycle&nbsp;and
determining the damage, a damage increment&nbsp;is applied, and the
number of cycles required to cause this damage increment is
calculated.&nbsp; This procedure preserves the ability to capture
stress redistribution, but cuts the number of loading cycles that
must be explicitly simulated from thousands or hundreds of
thousands to tens.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The MAC/GMC 4.0
fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis procedure is as follows for a
specified loading&nbsp;cycle&nbsp;and damage
increment&nbsp;(<span style='font-family:Symbol'>D</span><i>D</i>),
where locally, the damage parameter, <i>D</i>, varies between an
undamaged level of 0 and a completely damaged, or zero
stiffness&nbsp;level of 1.0:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)<span style=
'font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>
Apply specified thermo-mechanical loading&nbsp;cycle&nbsp;to the
composite or laminate</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)<span style=
'font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>
Determine number of cycles (<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>D</span><i>N</i>) required to increment the
local damage&nbsp;(<i>D</i>) in the first (most damaged)
controlling subcell&nbsp;by <span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>D</span><i>D</i>.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)<span style=
'font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>
Determine damage&nbsp;level in all other subcells due to
<span style='font-family:Symbol'>D</span><i>N</i> number of
cycles.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)<span style=
'font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>
Add <span style='font-family:Symbol'>D</span><i>N</i> to the
previous total number of cycles (<i>N</i>) to arrive at new total
number of cycles.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.5in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)<span style=
'font:7.0pt "Times New Roman"'>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span>
Re-apply the specified thermo-mechanical loading&nbsp;cycle, go to
step 2.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Clearly, when the specified loading&nbsp;is
applied to the damaged material in step 5, the resulting stress
field throughout the damaged composite or laminate&nbsp;will be
different than that experienced by the undamaged composite or
laminate after step 1.&nbsp; This redistribution&nbsp;of stresses
then affects the evolution of damage&nbsp;as the damage
increment&nbsp;(<span style='font-family:Symbol'>D</span><i>D</i>)
is repeatedly applied and the total number of cycle (<i>N</i>)
increases.&nbsp; When a particular subcell reaches a damage level
of 1.0, it has failed and (provided the RUC or laminate has not
completely failed) a new controlling subcell&nbsp;will be chosen
whose damage level will be incremented.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046526"
id="_Toc23046526"></a><a name="_Toc26088701" id=
"_Toc26088701">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 5d</b></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046527"
id="_Toc23046527"></a><a name="_Toc26088702" id=
"_Toc26088702">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; Execution of a MAC/GMC 4.0
fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;analysis will end when all
subcells&nbsp;(or RUCs) have failed, the code determines that the
remaining fatigue life is infinite, or <i>maxnb</i> load blocks
have been applied.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; A smaller damage&nbsp;increment&nbsp;(<i>dinc</i>)
value will generally cause the code to apply a greater number of
load load blocks prior to failure, leading to a larger
execution&nbsp;time.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The maximum value of <i>dmax</i> actually employed
by the code is 0.99999.&nbsp; This value is employed when a
<i>dmax</i> value of 1.0 is specified, which is a good default
value as it allows the subcells to damage&nbsp;almost
completely.&nbsp; A <i>D</i> value of exactly 1.0 causes a zero
stiffness&nbsp;for the subcell and leads to numerical
difficulties.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; As shown in Figure 5.1, the load block&nbsp;that
constitutes a single cycle of the applied
fatigue&nbsp;loading&nbsp;is associated with a portion of the
thermo-mechanical loading&nbsp;specified under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span> and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span> by
defining <i>t1</i> and <i>t2</i>.&nbsp; Because of the
cyclic&nbsp;nature of fatigue loading, the thermal
loading&nbsp;profile specified under <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*THERM</span></b></span> must
have the same temperature&nbsp;at <i>t1</i> and <i>t2</i> so that
the cycle starts and ends at the same temperature.&nbsp; Likewise,
each component of the mechanical loading specified under
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MECH</span></b></span> must have
the same magnitude at <i>t1</i> and <i>t2</i>.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;model parameters,
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol; color:black'>q</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>w</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>u</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>w</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>fl</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=

'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>m</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>

<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>
and</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>h</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>m</span></sub></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>
are applicable only to cases involving transversely
isotropic</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;subcell
materials.&nbsp; For isotropic subcell materials, the specified
value of</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>q</span></span> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>
is arbitrary, while</span></span> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>w</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>u</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>w</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>fl</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>w</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>m</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>h</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>u</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>h</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>fl</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>
and</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>h</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>m</span></sub></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>
should all be set equal to 1.0.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
6)&nbsp;&nbsp; For isotropic subcell materials, the parameters,
<i>b, b&CloseCurlyQuote;,</i> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>b</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>,
&acirc;,</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>s</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>fl</span></sub></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>,
M, and</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>s</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>u</span></sub></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black;font-style:normal'>
must be characterized for the materials based on experimental
material S-N curve</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>s.&nbsp;
If no mean stress</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;dependence
is desired,</span></span> <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>b</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black;font-style:normal'>
and</span></span> <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>b&CloseCurlyQuote;</span></span>
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black;font-style:normal'>
can be set to zero.&nbsp; See MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem 5d for an
example of how the stiffness reduction</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;fatigue</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;damage</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style='font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>&nbsp;model
parameter</span></span><span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black;font-style:normal'>s
are characterized.</span></span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
7)&nbsp;&nbsp; For additional information on the stiffness
reduction&nbsp;fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;model material parameters,
see the MAC/GMC 4.0 Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.3 and Arnold and
Kruch (1994).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
8)&nbsp;&nbsp; If any local failures or
interfacial&nbsp;debonding&nbsp;are detected during application of
a particular load block, the load block is repeated and one cycle
is added to the total number of cycles.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
9)&nbsp;&nbsp; Currently both the strength and the siffness
reduction fatigue&nbsp;damage&nbsp;models are isothermal and do not
admit temperature-dependent&nbsp;material properties.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>

<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046534"
id="_Toc23046534"></a><a name="_Toc26088704" id=
"_Toc26088704">*DEBOND</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Fiber-matrix
interfacial</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;debonding</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:2.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046535"
id="_Toc23046535"></a><a name="_Toc26088705" id=
"_Toc26088705">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Enable interfacial&nbsp;debonding&nbsp;between
the subcells within an RUC or laminate&nbsp;analysis.&nbsp; Two
debonding models are available within MAC/GMC 4.0.&nbsp; Both
models treat normal and shear interfacial debonding independently
and incorporate finite shear and normal bond strengths.&nbsp; The
constant compliant interface&nbsp;(CCI) model is formulated such
that, after debonding occurs at a particular interface, the
interfacial stress becomes a constant (for properly chosen model
parameters).&nbsp; The evolving compliant interface&nbsp;(ECI)
model, on the other hand, allows the interfacial stress to unload
and be redistributed after debonding occurs (again, for properly
chosen model parameters).&nbsp; While both models are made
available, the ECI is thought to capture the physics of debonding
better than the CCI model, especially when used in concert with
HFGMC, which allows more accurate local stress
redistribution&nbsp;than GMC.&nbsp; However, the CCI model may be
useful in some instances in which one desires to maintain a certain
amount of load carrying capacity subsequent to failure&nbsp;of the
interface.</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046536"
id="_Toc23046536"></a><a name="_Toc26088706" id=
"_Toc26088706">Usage:</a></h3>

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046538"
id="_Toc23046538"></a><a name="_Toc26088708" id=
"_Toc26088708">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 5e</b></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046539"
id="_Toc23046539"></a><a name="_Toc26088709" id=
"_Toc26088709">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>L=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>ly</span></span>
is only required in the special case&nbsp;of
laminate&nbsp;analysis.&nbsp; In this case, the
debonding&nbsp;parameters for the interfaces in the RUCs
representing each layer&nbsp;must be specified.&nbsp; If a layer
has no debonding interfaces, <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>LY=</span></span><i>ly</i>
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>NII=</span></span><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar"><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>0</span></span>,
should be specified (see Example above).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>NAI=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>nai</span></span>
is only required in the special case&nbsp;of a triply periodic
RUC.&nbsp; The triply periodic RUC may be part of a stand alone
triply periodic RUC analysis&nbsp;or may represent a particular
layer&nbsp;in a laminate&nbsp;analysis.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The units&nbsp;of <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>s</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>DB</span></sub></span>,
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>toln</span></span>,
and <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&tau;<sub>DB</sub></span></span>
must be consistent with the stress units employed throughout the
analyzed problem.&nbsp; The units of <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&Vcy;<sub>n</sub></span></span>
and <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&Vcy;<sub>s</sub></span></span>
are seconds, while the units of <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&Lambda;<sub>n</sub></span></span>
and <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>&Lambda;<sub>s</sub></span></span>
are 1/(stress units).</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The debonding&nbsp;parameters, <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&Lambda;<sub>n</sub></span></span>,
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>&Vcy;<sub>n</sub></span></span>,
<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&Lambda;<sub>s</sub></span></span>,
and <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&Vcy;<sub>s</sub></span></span>
are constants in evolution equations&nbsp;that affect the debonding
behavior of the interface.&nbsp; The form of these evolution
equations is different for the CCI&nbsp;and CCI models.&nbsp; See
the MAC/GMC 4.0 Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.4 for details on the
debonding model equations.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The reversal tolerance, <i>toln</i>, can be used to
force the interface&nbsp;to
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;close&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; when the normal
stress is smaller than the specified value.&nbsp; The
debonding&nbsp;model implementations within MAC/GMC 4.0 are such
that, when the normal stress at a debonded interface becomes
compressive, the interface
&OpenCurlyDoubleQuote;closes&CloseCurlyDoubleQuote; and reacquires
its original (perfectly bonded) normal stiffness.&nbsp; The
reversal tolerance sets a small tensile value for the interfacial
stress for the code to consider negligible.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
6)&nbsp;&nbsp; The time delay, <i>delay</i>, can be used to
artificially prevent debonding&nbsp;of the interface&nbsp;until
after the specified time.&nbsp; This can be useful in situations
where the user wished to disallow debonding during a portion of the
applied loading&nbsp;history.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046540"
id="_Toc23046540"></a><a name="_Toc26088710" id=
"_Toc26088710">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.4</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="Figlabel">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046541"
id="_Toc23046541"></a><a name="_Toc26088711" id=
"_Toc26088711">*CURTIN</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Curtin</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;effective fiber
breakage</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;model</span></span></h2>
</div>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046542"
id="_Toc23046542"></a><a name="_Toc26088712" id=
"_Toc26088712">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Enable the Curtin&nbsp;effective fiber
breakage&nbsp;model for subcells within a doubly periodic RUC (the
model is not applicable to triply periodic RUCs).&nbsp; The Curtin
model simulates the effects of fiber fracture&nbsp;and the unloaded
portion&nbsp;of the fiber in the vicinity of the fiber
fracture.&nbsp; The model uses statistical fiber strength&nbsp;data
in order&nbsp;to simulate the effects of the breaking and
subsequent load shedding&nbsp;of many fibers as one effective
fiber.&nbsp; The effective fiber stiffness is degraded as the
longitudinal stress in the fiber is increased.&nbsp; The effective
longitudinal fiber stress reaches a maximum, which can be used as a
failure&nbsp;stress for the effective fiber.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046543"
id="_Toc23046543"></a><a name="_Toc26088713" id=
"_Toc26088713">Usage:</a></h3>

<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046545"
id="_Toc23046545"></a><a name="_Toc26088715" id=
"_Toc26088715">Associated MAC/GMC 4.0 Example Problem(s):</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><b>Example 5f</b></p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046546"
id="_Toc23046546"></a><a name="_Toc26088716" id=
"_Toc26088716">Notes:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
1)&nbsp;&nbsp; <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style=
'font-size:10.0pt;color:blue'>L=</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:blue'>ly</span></span>
is only required in the special case&nbsp;of
laminate&nbsp;analysis.&nbsp; In this case, the Curtin&nbsp;model
parameters for the fibers in the doubly periodic RUCs representing
each layer&nbsp;must be specified.&nbsp; If a layer has no Curtin
model fibers, <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>LY=</span></span><i>ly</i>
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar">
<span style='font-size:10.0pt'>NCURT=0</span></span>, should be
specified.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
2)&nbsp;&nbsp; The units&nbsp;for the fiber diameter&nbsp;and
characteristic length, <i>d</i> and <i>l<sub>0</sub></i>, must have
consistent (length) units, but these units do not have to be
consistent with the remaining material property units.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
3)&nbsp;&nbsp; The units&nbsp;of <span class=
"normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:Symbol;color:black'>s</span></span><span class=
"normalitalicChar"><sub><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>0</span></sub></span>
and <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;color:black'>&tau;<sub>0</sub></span></span>
must be consistent with the stress units employed throughout the
rest of the problem.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
4)&nbsp;&nbsp; The shear stress sliding resistance&nbsp;at the
fiber-matrix interface, <span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
'font-family:"Times New Roman",serif; color:black'>&tau;<sub>0</sub></span></span>,
is the most difficult of the Curtin&nbsp;model parameters to
obtain.&nbsp; Researchers have often attempted to deduce a value
for this parameter from fiber push out and pull out tests on the
composite.&nbsp; This parameter may also be chosen based on
characterization&nbsp;vs. a known longitudinal composite
stress-strain curve&nbsp;that is taken to failure.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
5)&nbsp;&nbsp; The time delay, <i>delay</i>, can be used to
artificially prevent activation of the Curtin&nbsp;model until
after the specified time.&nbsp; This can be useful in situations
where the user wishes to disallow fiber stiffness degradation
and/or breakage&nbsp;during a portion of the applied
loading&nbsp;history.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in;text-indent:-.25in'>
&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">&nbsp;</p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046547"
id="_Toc23046547"></a><a name="_Toc26088717" id=
"_Toc26088717">Additional Information:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'>MAC/GMC 4.0
Theory Manual&nbsp;Section 5.5</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><br clear=
"all" style='page-break-before:auto'></span>
<div class="WordSection14">
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:1.0pt 4.0pt 1.0pt 4.0pt; background:#E0E0E0'>
<h1 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in;background:#E0E0E0'>
<a name="_Toc23046548" id="_Toc23046548"></a><a name="_Toc26088718"
id="_Toc26088718">Section 6 <span style='color:black'>: Results and
Data Output Keywords</span></a></h1>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">This section presents the four MAC/GMC 4.0
keywords that are related to the results&nbsp;of the analyzed
problem.&nbsp; These are:</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char1">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*PRINT</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span> Specify the level of
results&nbsp;data to be written to the MAC/GMC 4.0
output&nbsp;file</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*XYPLOT</span></b></span>
<span style='font-family: Symbol'>&REG;</span> Specify data to be
written to files for generating x-y scatter&nbsp;plots</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*PATRAN</span></b></span>&nbsp;<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Generate
results&nbsp;output&nbsp;for post-processing&nbsp;with MSC/PATRAN
software</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'>&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='margin-left:.25in'><span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*MATLAB</span></b></span>&nbsp;<span style=
'font-family:Symbol'>&REG;</span> Generate
results&nbsp;output&nbsp;for post-processing&nbsp;with MATLAB
software</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">The lowest level of data output&nbsp;in
MAC/GMC 4.0 is controlled with the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*PRINT</span></b></span> keyword,
which specifies the amount of data written to the ASCII&nbsp;format
MAC/GMC 4.0 output&nbsp;file.&nbsp; Next, the <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*XYPLOT</span></b></span> keyword
writes time-based output to ASCII files that can be used within
standard plotting software packages to generated x-y plots (such as
predicted composite stress-strain curves).&nbsp; Finally,
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*PATRAN</span></b></span>&nbsp;and <span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style=
'font-size:10.0pt'>*MATLAB</span></b></span>&nbsp;enable the
generation of data files to be read by the MSC/PATRAN and MATLAB
(the MathWorks, Inc.) software packages for generating fringe
plots&nbsp;that show the variation of the result fields over the
composite architecture.&nbsp; Generation of fringe plots with these
software packages requires the appropriate MAC/GMC 4.0 files
(distributed with the MAC/GMC 4.0) that work in concert with
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*PATRAN</span></b></span> and
<span class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char">
<b><span style='font-size:10.0pt'>*MATLAB</span></b></span>.</p>
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
</div>
<span style=
'font-size:11.0pt;font-family:"Times New Roman",serif'><br clear=
"all" style='page-break-before:auto'></span>
<div class="WordSection15">
<p class="MsoNormal">&nbsp;</p>
<div style=
'border:none;border-bottom:solid windowtext 1.0pt;padding:0in 0in 1.0pt 0in'>
<h2 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046549"
id="_Toc23046549"></a><a name="_Toc26088719" id=
"_Toc26088719">*PRINT</a>: <span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>Overall print output</span></span><span class=
"StyleHeading214ptNotBoldChar"><span style=
'font-size:14.0pt'>&nbsp;level for output file</span></span></h2>
</div>
<p class="MsoNormal" style='page-break-after:avoid'><span style=
'font-size:6.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046550"
id="_Toc23046550"></a><a name="_Toc26088720" id=
"_Toc26088720">Purpose:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="MsoNormal">Specify the level of output&nbsp;data to be
written to the MAC/GMC 4.0 ASCII&nbsp;output file</p>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:6.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<h3 style='margin-left:0in;text-indent:0in'><a name="_Toc23046551"
id="_Toc23046551"></a><a name="_Toc26088721" id=
"_Toc26088721">Usage:</a></h3>
<p class="MsoNormal"><span style=
'font-size:8.0pt'>&nbsp;</span></p>
<p class="Code10BoldCharCharCharCharChar1Char">*PRINT</p>
<p class=
"Code10CharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharCharChar1CharCharCharCharCharCharChar1Char2Char">
&nbsp; NPL=<span class="normalitalicChar"><span style=
